characters: INT/ EXT. FIRST CLASS CARRIAGE. MORNING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An expensive bathroom suite. Excess of marble and gold taps. Into the bath, a hand is scattering rupee notes. Hundreds and hundreds of notes, worth hundreds of thousands of rupees. The sound of a fist thumping on the bathroom door, furious shouting from the other side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Salim! Salim! 2   INT. STUDIO. BACKSTAGE. DAY. Darkness. Then, glimpses of faces. In the half-light, shadowy figures move with purpose. An implacable voice announces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ten to white-out, nine, eight, seven...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you ready? Silence. A hand shakes a shoulder a little too roughly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said are you ready?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. 3   INT. JAVED'S SAFE-HOUSE. BATHROOM. NIGHT. The thumping at the door continues. The sound of mumbled Indian prayer. Dull gleam of a pistol. A hand cracks the chamber open. Loads a single bullet into the chamber, snaps the chamber shut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...three, two, one, zero. Cue Prem, cue applause... Suddenly, the door splinters as it is smashed through. A burst of gun-fire and white light as suddenly... 4   INT. STUDIO. NIGHT. ...we are back in the studio, the gun-fire morphing into rapturous applause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go, Prem. A wall of light and noise as the two walk on stage. Cheering, music, banks of searing studio lights. On stage, Jamal, an eighteen year-old Indian boy-man stares, petrified. He would surely turn and run but for the iron grip on his shoulder of the smiling host, Prem Kumar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welcome to Who Wants To Be A Millionaire! More applause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please give a warm welcome to our first contestant of the night- a local from our very own Mumbai! Under cover of the wild applause, Prem ushers Jamal towards the guest's chair, leaning in and hissing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smile, dammit. The lights seem to bore into him but Jamal manages a tentative smile. Out of nowhere, a hand slaps him ferociously across the face. Then again and again. Blood trickles from his mouth. 5   INT. POLICE INTERVIEW ROOM. NIGHT. The studio lights have seamlessly transformed into the harsh bulb of an interrogation light. Jamal is strung from the ceiling by his arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your name, bhen chod. Constable Srinivas's hand pulls back Jamal's head by the hair, forcing him to stare directly into the lights.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your name!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jamal Malik. And seamlessly we are back....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...on the set of Who Wants to be a Millionaire. Prem leans back in his chair, a man at home in his surroundings. Jamal sits opposite, frozen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, Jamal, tell us a bit about yourself. Close on Jamal's face. Without warning, it is shoved under water. 7   INT. BUCKET. NIGHT. We look up from the bottom of the bucket at the screaming face of a drowning man. His head shakes desperately, pointlessly. Then Jamal's face is dragged up again, roaring for breath. Close on his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I work in a call centre. In Juhu. 8   INT. STUDIO. NIGHT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Phone-basher! And what type of call centre would this be?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: XL 5. Mobile phones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aha! So, you're the man who rings me up every single day of my life with Special Offers, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, actually, I'm an assistant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An Assistant Phone-basher? A raised eye-brow at the audience. Amusement ruffles through them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what does an Assistant Phone- basher do, exactly?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I- I get tea for people and-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - a chi-wallah! Why didn't you say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laughter in the audience.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, ladies and gentlemen, Jamal Malik from Mumbai, let's play Who Wants To Be A Millionaire...!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jamal's body dangles motionless from the ceiling. His head is bowed and he is moaning to himself. The ceiling fan thumps round slowly. In the corner, Constable Srinivas mops his brow and lights a cigarette. Hot work. The door opens and the Inspector of Police walks in. A rumpled man in his late forties who has seen pretty much everything. He eyes Jamal, surprised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Has he confessed, yet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Apart from his name, I can't get a word out of the runt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've been here all bloody night, Srinivas. What have you been doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Srinivas shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tough guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little electricity will loosen his tongue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Constable Srinivas brings a box and a tangle of wires out of a cupboard and proceeds to put crocodile clips on Jamal's fingers. The Inspector stares, deep in thought. Sweat trickles down his face. He wipes it away with a handkerchief, seems to be talking to himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every night I get home, "why can't we have a/c like Bajan Chacha?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you care about your poor family, dying in this heat." Twenty-four years a policeman and I can't afford bloody a/c.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Turns on Jamal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you. You've got ten million rupees ek dum guaranteed, yaar? And who knows how much further? Fancy the twenty million, do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jamal just stares.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you probably do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Inspector nods absently to Constable Srinivas who turns a handle. Jamal's body pulsates and jerks. He screams. His body goes limp again. The Inspector goes over to Jamal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So. Were you wired up? A mobile or a pager, correct? Some little hidden gadget? No? A coughing accomplice in the audience? Microchip under the skin, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Constable Srinivas hadn't thought of that. Grabs Jamal's arms and starts squeezing them all over until the Inspector has had enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Srinivas! Look, it's hot, my wife is giving me hell, I've got a desk full of murderers, rapists, extortionists, assorted bum-bandits...and you. Why don't you save us both a lot of time? Hmm?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jamal doesn't answer. The Inspector sighs and sits down. Looks at his watch, nods at Constable Srinivas again. Jamal's body jerks with electric current. When the shudders and screams have subsided, the Inspector goes over to Jamal's collapsed form. Clicks his fingers in front of Jamal's face to check for a response.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's unconscious, chutiya. What good is that? How many times have I told you-?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, Sir.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: An excited Young Police Constable sticks his head around the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's coming! Sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ArГ© wa, Srinivas, we'll have Amnesty International in here next, peeing their pants about human rights. Get him down, tidy him up, for God's sake. Constable Srinivas goes over to Jamal and starts to undo the crocodile clips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe he did know the answers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you gone soft, Srinivas? Professors, lawyers, doctors, General Knowledge Wallahs never get beyond sixteen thousand rupees. And he's on ten million? What the hell can a slum dog possibly know? Jamal lifts his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The answers. He lifts his head, spits blood out of his mouth and says again, straight into the Inspector's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know the answers. Titles. Slum Dog Millionaire. 11   EXT. CRICKET GROUND. DAY. Bright sunlight filtered through the ever-present Mumbai dust. A group of children are playing cricket on a tarmac cricket ground. They are bare-foot, dressed in little more than rags, wiry-skinny and fast on their feet. Salim, a nine-year old, polishes the ball on his almost non-existent shorts, comes in with surprising speed and bowls. The batsman hooks it high in the air. The bowler screams at a boy in the outfield.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jamal! Catch it! Catch it! The seven-year old Jamal stares up at the ball, jinks around trying to get into position.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He pays no heed to the rest of the children who are scattering fast to the edges of the tarmac. The ball seems suspended in the blue sky. Shouts from the other children seem very far away. He doesn't notice that they are screaming for him to get out of the way. Jamal adjusts his feet for the perfect catch. Then out of nowhere, a light aircraft almost takes his head off as it comes in to land on the tarmac runway. Jamal is knocked to his feet by the down-draft of the plane. The ball bounces away. Also flattened, Salim gets to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How could you drop that? It was a sitter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then Salim's face turns to one of alarm. 12   EXT. AIRPORT PERIMETER. DAY. At the back of a pack of children, carrying a piece of wood crudely fashioned into a sword, Jamal is running for his life, pursued by an ancient but surprisingly nimble Security Guard from the airport who is screaming abuse and wielding a long stick. The kids dash across a rubbish dump and disappear down dozens of tiny lanes that run in between the shacks of the slum.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Private-ka land! Private-ka land! The planes won't kill you, mader chod, I will!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jamal and Salim- also with a wooden sword- break off, head down a separate lane. The Guard pursues them. 13   INT. JUHU SLUM. DAY. The lanes in between the corrugated iron shacks are three feet wide, with an open drain running down the middle. Many of the precarious upper floors of the shacks have been built right over the paths, turning them into black tunnels. Tunnels shot through with slivers of light. If you didn't live here, you would be lost and frightened in minutes. But these children are natives and with the practice of many years, Jamal and Salim zig-zag down the warren of lanes. They dodge past people cooking in the doorways, sleeping, washing clothes or in the case of Vinod, a naked four year-old, pissing into the drain. Salim shouts a warning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vinod! Musketeers coming through!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Without breaking step, they both jump expertly over the stream of piss. Not so the Security Guard who gets it all over his trousers, but doesn't stop the pursuit. The two children charge past a shack filled to the roof with chickens in cages who all start squawking. They break out into the sunlight of the `main road' of the slum lined with shops. It is packed: with people, stalls, bicycles and cows. All modern India is here, drinking tea, shouting at each other, selling food, playing carom, video games. Leaving a trail of shouting and wreckage behind them, the pair approach a brand new Mercedes almost blocking the lane. Beside it stands Javed, an impressive man in a beautiful suit and his two Minders. Jamal and Salim skid to a stop, put their hands together in respectful greeting and edge ever so carefully past the immaculate paintwork of the car. Still in pursuit, the Security Guard also slides carefully past the car with deprecating bows and smiles. On past the chi stall where a crowd has gathered to watch a hindi film blaring from the tv rigged up overhead. The irate Security Guard gets tangled up in a bicycle. Jamal and Salim stop to give him a taunting, hip-gyrating parody of the dance on the tv before scooting down another tunnel. They break out into sunlight again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jamal!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jamal skids to a halt, bumping into Salim who is already frozen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit. Mummy-ji.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you move a muscle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Security Guard arrives and he too skids to a halt at the sight of Jamal's mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Mister Gupta. I will deal with these two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Guard puts his hands together in grudging respect as Jamal's Mother lifts each skinny kid off the floor by their t-shirt and marches them down the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two renegades are dumped by Jamal's Mother into their desks as Mister Nandha hands out ancient school books.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, the musketeers return. We are honoured. Salim. Or Porthos, isn't it? He crashes the heavy book down on his head. Salim opens the book. Jamal glances over and turns the book the right way round for Salim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know! Mister Nandha hovers over Jamal's head. He winces in anticipation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Athos. The book comes down like thunder. Jamal blinks from the impact and suddenly we are back.... 15   INT. INSPECTOR'S OFFICE. DAY. ... in the Inspector's office. Jamal watches Srinivas fiddling with the video recorder, trying to get a picture. Through the pebbled glass, Jamal sees shapes moving along the corridor. 16   INT. CORRIDOR. POLICE STATION. DAY. The Commissioner of Police is fawning along beside Prem as they walk. The Young Constable hurries behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is so kind of you to visit our station, Sir. A great honour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not at all, not at all. I hope you will visit us, Commissioner. Out of his jacket pocket comes a couple of tickets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bring the family. It's a lot of fun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh! A thousand thanks, Sir. Missus Janda will be overcome.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He turns to the Young Constable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: chi, you lazy chutiyГ©, chi!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Inspector joins them in the corridor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, Inspector! Cracked it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Inspector moves his head. Maybe yes, maybe no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nearly, Sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Commissioner is just able to contain his apoplexy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nearly? Nearly? When Prem Kumar himself has-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prem holds up a tolerant hand to the Commissioner who falls silent. Turns his laser-like charm onto the Inspector.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inspector. How good to meet you. Clearly the kid cheated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clearly, Sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, it is just a question of how, no?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indeed, Sir. The proof. That is all we need.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are lucky to have a man of your obvious experience on the case. This kid might run rings around us filmi types, but he won't make fools out of the Mumbai Police Force, I can see that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forced laughter from the Commissioner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In front of sixty million people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More laughter. And fear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which is what will happen if we don't get a result, Gentlemen. He goes back on the show to rob us all with the whole of India watching. But. I can rely on you. Prem walks away down the corridor. Stops and turns, apparently casual.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Has he- has he made any allegations?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Allegations?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a cunning one. A convincing liar. Don't be taken in, Inspector, don't be taken in. Walks off. The Inspector stares after him. Goes back into his office. 17   INT. INSPECTOR'S OFFICE. Srinivas has finally got the recorder to work. We get snatches of filmi dancing- heroines singing on mountainsides surrounded by implausible numbers of flags- cricket and finally after some shouting by the Inspector, Who Wants to Be A Millionaire?.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, Mister Malik, the man who knows the answers. Talk. We close in on the tv screen where Prem is smiling his crocodile smile and find ourselves.... 18   INT. STUDIO. NIGHT. ...as Prem asks the first question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, are you ready for your first question for one thousand rupees?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not bad money to sit in a chair and answer a question. Better than making the tea, no?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Yes. No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Yes. No. Apka final answer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laughter from the audience. Jamal looks confused. Prem waves it away, switches on his serious face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remember, you have three lifelines if you're not sure of your answer- Ask the Audience, 50/50 and Phone a Friend. So, the question:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lights go down, the portentous music rolls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who was the star of the 1973 hit film Zanjeer. Was it A-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close on Jamal's eyes. 19   INT. SHACK. NIGHT. A tiny shack. A garland of dirty plastic flowers surrounds a torn flyer for one of Amitabh Bacchan's films. 20   EXT. JUHU SLUM. RUBBISH DUMP. NIGHT. Salim is sitting on a chair at the end of a rickety wooden pier, though it is not water, but a sea of rubbish and sewage that lies below them. There are dozens of these piers protruding from the slum onto airport land, each with a toilet shack perched right at the end. Another man hurries up the pier and hands Salim a coin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Immediately, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Turns to the toilet door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bhai, get out of there. Prakash wants a shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not finished.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop your time-pass. This is urgent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a shy one. Since when was there a time limit on a crap?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Since there was a customer waiting, that's when.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He flashes another placatory smile at Prakash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing/ grunting) Come on out, you beauty, unveil yourself, my darling-warling....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, kid, I got a bad stomach. It's borderline....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A disturbing combination of heaving and snake-charmer noises come from the toilet shack. Finally Prakash can stand it no longer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm off to Devi's bog. Give me that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He snatches the coin back from Salim and hurries off. Salim bangs on the toilet door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You just lost me good money, you stupid idiot-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Salim stops. In the distance, there is the faint sound of shouting, a crowd coming closer. Then the crowd bursts through the outer shacks of the slum, pour onto the rubbish dump and make for the airfield.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Amitabh! That's his helicopter!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amitabh? Amitabh Bacchan?

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. TOILET. NIGHT.
dialogues.text: Jamal peers through one of the many cracks in the shack. He sees crowds surging around the pier, charging towards a landing helicopter. Salim shoves the chair under the door handle- effectively locking it- and runs down the pier to join the chase. Jamal pulls up his shorts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! Wait! Salim, sala! Salim!

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Rattles the locked door. Pulls a torn flyer from his pocket advertising an Amitabh movie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait! Amitabh....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks down the toilet hole at the sewage beneath him, the landing helicopter, the disappearing crowd. A final rattle of the door. There is only one way out. He jumps down the hole, sprawling headlong into a year's worth of human waste, managing to keep the flyer out the mire. He runs for the helicopter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amitabh-ji! Amitabh-ji!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Salim is at the back of the crowd, trying to force a way through, but the adults shove him back. Not so for Jamal. The down-draft from the helicopter flicks bits of sewage from his clothes. Disgusted fans curse him and get out of his way. Suddenly, the red sea parts and there is nobody between Jamal and Amitabh Bacchan getting out of the helicopter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please. Amitabh-ji.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jamal holds out his flyer. Used to signing autographs, the movie star barely looks at Jamal. He takes the flyer and scribbles his autograph on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A thousand thanks, Amitabh-ji.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hands the flyer back to Jamal as his bodyguards surround him and hustle him into a car. Jamal chases the flyer across the tarmac, grabs it. Kisses it. 22   EXT. JUHU SLUM. NIGHT. From high up, the rickety tin roof-tops of the slum seem to stretch to the horizon. There is a distant shout, a figure waving an arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's coming!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then another shout and another, a chain of voices coming closer. People come out of their doorways with pails and buckets. The shouts come closer until we see a naked figure entirely encased in bubbles dancing and singing in the lane. Jamal is the happiest boy in the slum.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing) Amitabh, Amitabh, oh Amitabh!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have your autograph, oh, holy Amitabh!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here it comes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Water comes bubbling through a hose and Jamal's mother hoses down her ecstatic son. 23   EXT. JUHU SLUM. NIGHT. Not far away, Salim wanders to Mister Chi's stall. He glances around to make sure everybody is glued to the hindi film on Mister Chi's tv and surreptitiously slips Mister Chi the signed flyer. Mister Chi takes a look and gives Salim a small wad of rupees. He sticks the money in his pocket, slinks away. 24   EXT. JUHU SLUM. NIGHT. A tear-stained Jamal is furiously trying to batter Salim, but Salim's extra strength and height means that he can keep Jamal at bay with one hand, Jamal's flailing fists punching thin air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sala! Sala!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Salim's laughter only makes Jamal cry harder. 25   INT. INSPECTOR'S OFFICE. NIGHT. Close on the tv screen in the Inspector's office. Prem ponders Jamal's choice. Presses a button on his computer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You chose A- Amitabh Bacchan. Guess what? You just won one thousand rupees!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Applause on screen. The Inspector looks at Jamal. Jamal shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't have to be a genius.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew it was Amitabh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like I said.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Constable Srinivas twists Jamal's arm behind his back, evincing a squeal of pain from Jamal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (squealing) He's the most famous man in India...!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Inspector stares at Jamal, turns back to the tv where Prem is asking the next question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For four thousand rupees....the national emblem of India is a picture of three lions. What is written underneath? Is it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...A) The truth alone triumphs. B) Lies alone triumph. C) Fashion alone triumphs. D) Money alone triumphs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prem shoots a mock puzzled look out to the audience eliciting giggles from them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do we think, Jamal? The most famous phrase in our country's history. Maybe you want to phone a friend?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laughter from the audience. The studio lights bear down on Jamal. a drop of sweat trickles down his forehead. Prem is loving his discomfort.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or Ask the Audience? I have a hunch they might just know the answer. What do we think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gestures expansively at his audience. Oh, they love him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (startled) Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ask the audience.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prem whistles. Raises his eyes at the audience.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you're the contestant, Jamal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put the poor man out of his misery, Ladies and Gentlemen. Press your key-pad now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lights dim. Portentous music. 27   INT. INSPECTOR'S OFFICE. DAY. The Inspector presses pause. Sighs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, Jamal. My five-year-old daughter knows the answer to that, but you don't. Strange for a millionaire genius. What happened? Your accomplice nip out for a piss, did he? Or did he just not cough loud enough?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence. Constable Srinivas kicks Jamal's chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Inspector asked you a question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much is bhelpuri at Jeevan's stall on Chowpatty Beach?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One bhelpuri. How much?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (can't help himself) Ten rupees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wrong. Fifteen since Divali. Who stole Constable Varma's bicycle outside Dadar Station last Thursday?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (amused) You know who that was?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone in Juhu knows that. Even five year-olds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Despite himself, the Inspector laughs. Then leans in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll give you five hundred rupees if you just admit it. You go home, I go home. Everybody happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jamal just stares back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, you want to go back on the programme and win twenty million rupees, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wouldn't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The audience has chosen. And, whaddya know? Ninety-nine percent of them think the answer is A). The truth alone triumphs. What do we think, Jamal? A hundred percent would have made me a little more reassured, maybe....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prem shrugs, makes a show of examining his computer. Suddenly fixes him with his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you married, Jamal?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, don't despair, there's someone out there who thinks our national motto is "Fashion alone triumphs". You two could be very well matched.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Audience laughter. 29   INT. GALLERY. NIGHT. The Director is shaking his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the bloody hell is he playing at? He's way off script...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Split up with his girl-friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which one?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All three, I heard. Nita as well. Back with the wife. She's pregnant again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, God, that's all we need....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, for Sharukh Khan...Stand by white out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...won four thousand rupees!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Music, lights, applause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One more question before the commercial break. What will our Call Centre Assistant do next?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lights dim. Prem presses his computer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Religion! Interesting. For sixteen thousand rupees, in depictions of the God Ram, he is famously holding what in his right hand? Is it A) a flower. B) a scimitar. C) a child or D) a bow and arrow?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right next to the railway lines is a pond of dirty water surrounded by shacks in which dozens of women are washing clothes. Trains flash past only feet away from them. Down the other end of the pond, nine-year old Jamal and Salim are splashing noisily with some other children. Jamal's mother pauses in her scrubbing, wipes sweat from her forehead and gazes up at the leaden sky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's going to come. Today. I can feel it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The woman next to her nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hope so. My head is exploding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. We need rain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jamal is trying to intercept the ball that Salim and Krishna are throwing to each other. He's not having much success. The ball flies overhead again from Salim to Krishna. Jamal dives for it, misses and goes underwater. When he comes up for air, he shakes his head, clearing his ears of water. Then he stops, listens. Shakes his head again. Definitely something strange. Thunder? Salim and Krishna are trading catches, unaware that anything has changed. But Jamal's mother has heard it too. The faintest sound of shouting, roaring. The wave of noise is still faint but getting louder. A frozen moment broken by:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Run! Jamal, Salim, run!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody stares at her. A train speeds through as she continues to shout, her words lost beneath the thundering train.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go! Run!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The train goes through, the last carriage flying past suddenly opening up the sight of a wall of rioting men wielding clubs, scythes, metal bars. They come screaming across the railway tracks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Krishna, quick!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Salim holds out his hand to Krishna who is wading with difficulty through the water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No way! You're a bloody Muslim. Get away from me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rioters leap the tracks and are upon them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're Muslims! Him and him!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Salim and Jamal scramble out and retreat into the lanes. Salim turns to see his Mother felled by a rioter. She is surrounded by screaming, chanting men who rain blows down on her. Jamal runs back and drags Salim down an alley. As they head down the alley, they get glimpses of burning houses, fleeing women, a three- year old boy in a doorway, painted entirely in garish blue. He stares at them. In his hand, he is carrying a bow and arrow. An eleven-year old girl dressed only in a pair of pants runs after them.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She has two bleeding red gashes on her back. They turn a corner and head towards some vans full of police. Jamal sees Mister Nandha, the school teacher, stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Salim! Then Mister Nandha starts walking towards him. An oasis of calm in the chaos. Jamal looks at him with relief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mister Nandha. Mister Nandha smiles, walks towards them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ram nam satya hai, Babri Masjid dhvasth hai.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mister Nandha?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have destroyed your mosque. Now, the followers of Ram will drive you dogs out of our city. From behind his back he produces a knife and runs towards Jamal, screaming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ram has returned to his temple! Ram has returned! They flee, but Jamal turns, sees the girl, frozen. He chases back a few steps, hauls her arm. The spell broken, and they are off. 32   INT. STREET. EVENING. They reach the safety of the police vans. But inside the vans, the police are smoking, laughing, playing cards. Down the street, a man comes whirling out of a doorway, his hair on fire. He falls into the middle of the street and is engulfed by rioters. Unperturbed, the police continue to chat. Salim and Jamal look on, horrified. Then one of the police men turns, looks at them. Is interested. Motions to a colleague. Puts out his cigarette with purpose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's go, bhai. Salim and Jamal run. The girl follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Salim and Jamal stand on a hill overlooking the city. Black smoke billows from a large area that is clearly the Juhu slum. Standing a little way off is the girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We should go back. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See if Ama- Salim shakes his head fiercely, silencing Jamal for a moment. But only a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about Jeevan Chacha? Salim shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe he- Salim shakes his head again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - I saw him. He was with them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But he wouldn't hurt-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - he was with them!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - shut up, Jamal, can't you? Just shut up! Salim turns away and sees the girl. Picks up a rock and hurls it at her. She dodges, takes a couple of steps back but makes no real attempt to get away. He finds another rock and hurls this in her direction too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ja! Then a flash of lightning and thunder rumbles across the city. Rain begins to come down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What shall we do?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: No answer. Jamal sits down. Salim sits down. At a distance, the girl sits down. Rain pours down their faces. 34   INT. BUILDER'S YARD. NIGHT. Rain as you've never seen. A pile of huge water pipes in a sprawling builder's yard. Jamal is in one pipe, Salim above him in another. They are both soaked, shivering, but have found some plastic sheet to wrap themselves in. Outside, thirty feet away, stands the girl. Staring. Salim hisses angrily at the girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go away. Ja, ja!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girl might not even have heard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She'll have the Security Guard onto us, standing there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not if we let her in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She could be the third musketeer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am the head of this family, now. And I say no. Piss off, you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Salim huddles down in the pipe. After a while, Jamal follows suit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't even know what the third musketeer's called.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. JUHU SLUM. DAY
dialogues.text: A flash of Jamal's mother being clubbed to the ground. Her scream. 36   INT. BUILDER'S YARD. LATER. Jamal wakes with a jolt and a scream half-swallowed in his mouth. He shuts his eyes tight, trying to force the image out. His breathing slows and he sees the girl staring at him. Salim, too, is staring into nothing. The rain is still falling.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The girl goes back to drawing shapes in the mud with her finger. Jamal climbs out of the pipe. Looks at Salim for permission or refusal, but he just continues to stare. So, Jamal walks across to her. She looks up, wary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's your Mother?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girl shakes her head slightly. Jamal takes the plastic sheet from around his shoulders. Gives it to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Jamal. He's Salim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Latika.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jamal goes back to his water pipe, climbs in. Watches her huddled under the sheet. Sighs, motions for her to join him. She darts across, jumps into the water pipe and huddles up next to Jamal. 37   INT. INSPECTOR'S OFFICE. DAY. Jamal looks at the Inspector.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wake up every morning wishing I didn't know the answer to that question? If it wasn't for Ram and Allah, I would still have a Mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: D) A bow and arrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Final answer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Final answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prem stares at him for dramatic effect. Presses his computer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Computer-ji, D lock kiya-jaye.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The lights dim, the music swells.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jamal Malik, you answered D? Ram is depicted with a bow and arrow in his hand. And guess what? You've just won sixteen thousand rupees! Well done, my friend. Time for a commercial break- don't go away, now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Music, applause. Prem switches off his professional smile. Gets up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got lucky, huh? I'd take the money. You'll never get the next one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're from the Juhu slum, aren't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmm? Sure. Know where I live now, kid? Pali Hill. Twelve bedrooms, a/c in every room, two kitchens, a gym and a screening room. Steel balls is what it takes, my friend, steel balls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Floor Manager comes over and gives his head-phones set to Prem. Prem listens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prem? Tone it down, for goodness sake. You're making him a laughing stock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prem glances up at the gallery with contempt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're having fun here. They love it...Where the hell do you get them from?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He makes no attempt to hide the conversation from Jamal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's supposed to be a quiz show, not a blood sport.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop wetting your pants. I'll be a good little boy with the next one. Promise. He chucks the head-phones back at the Floor Manager. Glances in the wings. Sees Nita, the make-up woman. Gets up and goes over. 39   INT. STUDIO. BACKSTAGE. NIGHT. In the half-light, backstage, Nita dabs his face with powder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meet me after the show. Please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nita, I can explain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No need. I read it in bloody Stardust. Didn't even have the balls to tell me. "Prem's happiness with another baby on the way". After everything you said...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baby, it all happened before I met you. I swear to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's got the gestation period of an elephant, then. Prem is about to object. But instead, he laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see? Amidst all this misery, only you can make me laugh. Scornful but hints of melting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All this misery...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her and I- nothing. You have to believe me, baby... Nita turns away. The Floor Manager comes over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One minute.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Prem slings himself in a chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I'm not going on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prem...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't. Without you, it's all pointless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clicks his fingers at the Floor Manager.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You. Tell the Director.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nita shakes her head at the Floor Manager who by now is looking very worried.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thirty seconds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prem shrugs and folds his arms. Sees her weaken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prem...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Calypso Bar, private room, just you and me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fifteen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (furious) Alright.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He grins, jumps up, blows her a kiss, and stalks back on stage. 40   INT. STUDIO. NIGHT. He sits back down, says almost to himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steel balls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Turns to Jamal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, Juhu boy, you've had a good run. Take your Mother to Khandala and eat some chiki.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My Mother's dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, your girlfriend then. Even better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't have a girl-friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Live wire like you? You surprise me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five, four...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The warm-up man starts the applause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ....three, two, one...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cheering and music. Prem switches on his charm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welcome back to Who Wants to be a Millionaire! Our contestant, Jamal Malik, Call Centre Assistant- from Mumbai, is on sixteen thousand rupees and has already used one lifeline: Ask the Audience. So, my friend: are you ready for the next question?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then, let's play.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Portentous music. The lights dim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For sixty-four thousand rupees. The British architect Frederick Stevens designed which famous building in India? Is it: A) The Taj Mahal. B) Chhatrapati Shivaji Terminus. C) India Gate. D) Howrah Bridge. What do you think, Jamal? Are you one of those tea-boys with a penchant for architecture?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Known to everyone as VT station, this monument to Victorian railway architecture is a dangerous place to be at rush hour.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Even before the train has stopped, men are jumping from the open doors, or vaulting out of the windows or from the roof of the train to join the tens of thousands of Mumbaites streaming to and from work. A seventeen-year old Jamal squeezes himself out of a train and shoves through the crowds. He checks the time. The digital numerals flick to five O'clock. Looks around the tide of humanity. 42   INT. STUDIO. NIGHT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, what's it to be? Walk away and this cheque for sixteen thousand rupees is yours. Look, it's even got your name on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He produces a cheque and waves it at Jamal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't have a bank account.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laughter from the audience. Prem is momentarily wrong- footed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I'll take cash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More laughter, this time with Jamal, rather than at him. Prem gets up and starts rummaging theatrically through his jacket pockets and trousers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nope. Looks like the Producer's stolen my wallet again-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - I'll play.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody was expecting this. Least of all Prem who has to rearrange his features into one of surprised delight. He sits down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll play?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, well, well. We've got a wild one, here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prem tears up the cheque with theatrical slowness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For sixty-four thousand rupees, Ladies and Gentlemen, the question once again....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The digital clocks show five fifteen. Shoving the descending river of people out of his way, the eighteen year-old Jamal is forging a path up steps that cross the platforms. He pushes to the middle of the footbridge and leans out on the side railings. He scans the sea of people, desperately. Then he sees her: the eighteen year-old Latika, heart-stoppingly beautiful, over the other side of the station. A world away. She is scanning the crowd, as wired as he is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Latika! Latika!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But though he is screaming her name, his voice is swallowed by the noise around him. Then he sees two thuggish-looking men also fighting a way towards her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Latika!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frightened now, he fights his way down the steps, one figure against an army of white-robed people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Latika!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chhatrapati Shivaji Terminus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chhatrapati Shivaji Terminus. Sure?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think so. A brave man, Ladies and Gentlemen, a brave man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The commuters have mostly gone. Jamal is pacing the platform desperately. He stops, stares blankly at the statue in front of him- a proud, rather pompous figure in a Victorian frock coat. The plaque reads: Frederick Stevens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Inspector, Srinivas and Jamal are staring at the video recorder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Final answer. Chhatrapati Shivaji Terminus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is the right answer! Sixty-four thousand rupees to you, Sir! Applause and music. The Inspector presses pause. Stares at Jamal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And did she come back? Jamal smiles sadly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wouldn't be here if she had.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pretty was she? Jamal stares down at his feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guess not. Right in the eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The most beautiful woman in the world. Constable Srinivas snorts. Suddenly, Jamal is out of his chair and at Srinivas' throat. The combined force of the Inspector and Srinivas force him roughly back down. He is again handcuffed to the chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, well. The slum dog barks. Money or women. The reason for most mistakes in life. Looks like you got mixed up with both. Srinivas, you need the exercise: a trip to VT Station to check on the statue. And lock your bloody bike up. Constable Srinivas swears under his breath but bumbles out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the chutiyГ© out the way. Now, man to man. How did you know all the answers?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I knew, I'd tell you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now we're into the serious money. For two hundred and fifty thousand rupees, ladies and gentlemen, a quarter of a million rupees...the song Chalo Ri Murali was written by which famous Indian poet. Was it A) Surdas. B) Tulsidas. C) Mira Bai. D) Kabir. Remember you still have two lifelines- fifty- fifty and Phone A Friend. Tempted to use one?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know this one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. I see. An expert on the poets, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lights dim, the music swells and Prem presses his computer. 49   EXT. MUMBAI STREET. NIGHT. Jamal is studying a piece of paper and reading out numbers from it. There is something not quite right about Jamal- perhaps the fact that there are two feet by his ears. Salim is standing on his shoulders and spraying the numbers on a wall with an aerosol and a certain lack of confidence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four, nine, zero, nine- the one with the stick going down, Salim- six- stick going up-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Latika's head appears from around the corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispered) Oi!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But they don't hear. Then she is running for her life past the pair of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Six, one, shit, let's go-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Salim collapses off Jamal's shoulders and all three run off down an alley past a dozen of the gang's sprayed-on adverts all reading: "Beanbags- 989 4909661". A fat Security Guard with a long stick huffs round the corner. Chases them up an alley. Nowhere to go except through an imposing gate that clearly leads to a private house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got you now, little shits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They charge across the lawn, down one side of the house where all the washing is hanging. The Guard gets caught up in drying sheets, towels. He fights his way through to see Salim, Latika and Jamal leaping over the wall to safety. But Jamal turns, jumps back and grabs a girl's dress from the line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aha! Little thief!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Security Guard lands a couple of blows on Jamal's back as he dodges around him and back across the lawn, dress in hand. The Security Guard gives up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pervert!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jamal is examing the bruises on his legs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Useless bloody look-out. What good is she, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (infuriated) I tried to warn you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's okay, Salim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Latika slips on the dress. Spins. Both of them look up. Stare. She pulls her hair back, smiles, is transformed into a beautiful girl. 52   EXT. GORAI BEACH DUMPING GROUND. DAY. Blazing sun. Diggers and trucks are shifting mounds of rubble on a rubbish dump that seems to stretch for ever. Oblivious to the dust kicked up by the trucks, Latika is picking up old plastic bags, examining each one and putting the less worn in a big sack. The dress is recognisable but dusty and torn. She stoops to dig another bag out of the dirt, but stops and stares. Shimmering in the heat, a rickety pick-up truck comes through the rubbish dump gates. Toots at the Guard who waves, pulls up in the dump. "Hope Orphanage is written on the side of the van. A man gets out. Looks around. 53   INT. `TENT'. DAY. Under sheets of plastic propped up on sticks, Jamal and Salim are sleeping out the hottest part of the day. Jamal wakes to see a figure standing over him- a silhouette with a halo of sun behind him. Out of his bag, the man produces a bottle of Thumbs Up. He uncaps it with an alluring hiss. It is almost an advert for thirst-quenching affluence. Almost instinctively, Salim and Jamal stir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hands the bottle to Salim, gets another from his bag and waves it questioningly at Jamal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hot, huh? My name is Maman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hills on the edge of Bombay. Greenery and space, for the first time in the film. The pick-up truck pulls up outside a building with Jamal, Salim and Latika sitting on a bench in the back. Maman gets out. Drops the gate on the back of the pick-up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyone hungry? Come on in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty children are eating at long benches in a ramshackle courtyard. Maman, ushers Jamal, Salim and Latika in and sits them down at one of the benches. He waves a hand and a giant man, Punnoose, comes over with a big bowl of food. The three tear into it. Cleaning every last morsel of rice from his plate, Jamal looks up and notices a table peopled entirely with blind or crippled children. Some of the legless are eating on the floor next to the table. Jamal leans over to Salim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He must be a very good man to look after these people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (glancing at them)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A saint. Arvind, a boy smaller than either Jamal or Salim overhears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're not allowed to talk to them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not? Arvind shrugs. Latika licks her plate, glances at Maman who is looking right at them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, if there are seconds, Maman is definitely a Saint. As if telepathic, Maman signals to Punnoose and he brings a large bowl of rice and dhal over to them. Latika looks at Jamal and Salim. They burst out laughing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I tell you, Lord Siva is with us. 56   INT. ORPHANAGE. EVENING. Salim, Latika, Jamal and a group of children are standing in a line singing a doha- ancient lyrics set to music. Maman is leading the singing, walking up and down the line listening to each one individually. He stops at one small boy, Arvind, and listens. Nods his head, pleased, and continues down the line until he stops in front of Jamal. Holds up his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop! You. Again.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Jamal starts singing again. He has the sweetest of voices. Untrained but pure. Maman smiles, ruffles Jamal's hair, impressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all join in. Maman continues down the line. He stops at Salim whose octave-slipping singing is lusty and appallingly out of tune. Maman winces and moves on. Standing next to Salim, Latika giggles. Immediately, Salim is on her. Before a fight breaks out, Punnoose pulls Salim off Latika and hurls him across the room. Salim gets up and charges at Punnoose. For a second, Punnoose is back-footed, but then pins Salim's arms to his side. Maman laughs. Approaches Salim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sing like one, and you fight like one. I think you've found your dog, Punnoose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A group of children are sitting in the jumble of concrete under a motorway flyover. Cars surround them, bumper to bumper. Latika and Jamal are playing an improvised hopscotch on concrete slabs. They are giggling, bumping into each other, tickling, laughing. Salim and Punnoose are sitting together, smoking. Salim is staring hard at Jamal and Latika until Punnoose grunts, a sign for Salim to clap his hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, let's go, let's go! It's not a bloody holiday!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The children get to their feet. Latika sighs, puts a patch over her eye and grabs a pair of crutches. Suddenly, the lame beggar. Salim goes over to one of the girls, who is carrying a sleeping baby. Puts out his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give me that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girl shakes her head. Salim grabs her by the hair in one hand and takes the baby with the other. He shoves her to the ground. The other children stare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Salim!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He challenges Jamal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What, chotГ© bhai? You got a problem?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He laughs and walks over to Latika.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here. For you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll earn double. I'm doing you a favour, Latika.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She doesn't want it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chup, Jamal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Latika turns away and begins to walk towards the cars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll drop it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He holds the baby up. Latika grabs the baby with a cry just as Salim releases it from his hands. Salim pinches the baby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Triple if it's crying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Latika snatches it away. Salim laughs, goes back to sitting with Punnoose. The children scatter to the cars trapped at the lights, tapping plaintively on the windows and making the universal begging gesture. 58   INT. ORPHANAGE. KITCHEN. NIGHT. Surrounded by beer bottles, Punnoose is slumped asleep by the kitchen door. Latika edges past, avoids the cook sleeping under the table and goes to a shelf laden with vegetables. She pulls down a bunch of chillies still on the vine, strips a few off and tip-toes out with them. 59   INT. ORPHANAGE. DORMITORY. NIGHT. Sleeping children, three or four to a mattress on the floor. Latika tip-toes around the mattresses. She pauses over one in particular where we see Salim, asleep. She carefully pulls up the sheet, delves underneath. Pleasant dreams cross Salim's sleeping face for a second. Then suddenly, he is bolt upright and screaming. He charges around the room clutching his genitals in agony.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Madher chod...!

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He sprints out of the room, wailing. 60   INT. ORPHANAGE. SHOWERS. NIGHT. The lights are on and two dozen children are screaming with laughter as Salim stands under the make-shift shower directing the water down his pants to his burning genitals, his face a picture of agony. Latika wipes crushed chillies from her hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're dead, sala.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She smiles and walks past Jamal with a shrug. Then Punnoose comes stalking in and the children scatter away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get back to bed, dogs! What the hell...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They taught me every song in the history of Indian music.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And why would they do that, I wonder?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a shack, Arvind is singing one of Surdas' bhajans in front of Maman and an old man who by his ragged appearance must be a villager. Punnoose and Salim sit behind Arvind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very good, very good. I am pleased, Arvind. He is ready.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ready?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maman nods to Punnoose. Before Arvind can turn round, Punnoose has covered his mouth with a cloth and after the briefest of struggles, Arvind's body goes limp. The villager puts an old tin box on the table. Taking the lid from the tin, he brings out a cloth and unwraps it. Inside is a spoon. He checks the edge with his thumb. Sharp. Douses it with a clear liquid from a bottle and passes it over a candle flame. The spoon whooshes with a high flame for a moment. The villager wipes it with the cloth nods to Punnoose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Salim!

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Utterly bemused, Salim nevertheless helps Punnoose lay Arvind on the table. The villager takes hold of Arvind's eyelid and pulls it open. He brings the spoon close. Suddenly, Salim is being sick in the corner of the shack. By the time he has turned back, the villager is wiping the spoon on a blood-soaked rag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Take him out the back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Punnoose picks up Arvind and carries him out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now the other one. Salim, go get Jamal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A frozen moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gunfighter Number One, isn't that right, Salim? The money, the women, the cars...you want them bad, huh? And why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maman gets out of his chair. Approaches Salim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The time has come to choose, yaar. The life of a slum dog or the life of a man. A real man. A gunfighter, Salim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maman holds Salim's head in his hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your destiny is in your hands, bhai. You can be me. Or nobody. Understand?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Maman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maman nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, brother, go get Jamal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Salim is frozen for another few seconds, then turns and walks out of the door. Punnoose appears at the door. Maman nods to him and he slips off after Salim. 62   INT. DORMITORY, ORPHANAGE. NIGHT. All the children are asleep apart from Jamal who is crouched underneath a couple of wash-basins.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He is talking through a plate-sized hole in the crumbling masonry. Latika's eyes can be seen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...weddings, government things, big parties. If Maman says my voice is ready. Big money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enough for a room?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Easily. Maybe an apartment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what Arvind said. On Harbour Road. You, me and Salim. The three musketeers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harbour Road! We can have ice cream from Babanji's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every day if we want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Salim appears at the door. Nods his head at Jamal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's my turn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good luck, Jamal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Latika's hand comes through the gap. Jamal takes it for a moment. Salim hisses at Jamal. He lets go of the hand and heads out. 63   EXT. PATH. NIGHT. Salim and Jamal walk along the path, Jamal humming happily. Salim checks behind him, sees Punnoose following.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, this is it, hey, bhai? The good life, here we come....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (conversationally) Athos.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jamal is suddenly alert. Slows

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Porthos?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Salim nods. Big smile. Puts a hand on Jamal's shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Salim guides Jamal into the shack where Maman and the Villager are waiting. Maman smiles. Punnoose slips in behind Salim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jamal, hello. You have done well. It's time for you to- turn professional.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sing me a song, yaar. How about Chalo Ri Murali, huh? My favourite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jamal opens his mouth, then closes it again. Holds out his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fifty rupees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shrugs) I've turned professional. What can I do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maman laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sala...!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He throws some notes at him. 65   EXT. SHACK. NIGHT. Outside, a giggle. Latika is peering through a gap in the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jamal begins to sing. Maman waits a while, then nods to Punnoose. Behind Jamal, Punnoose hands Salim the bottle of chloroform and the rag. Salim approaches the back of Jamal. Salim waits until he has finished the song. Raises his hand with the rag in it. Maman smiles, nods. Salim flings the contents of the bottle in Punnoose's face. Punnoose screams and stumbles back clutching his eyes, knocking over the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go! Salim and Jamal scramble for the door. The knocked-over candle catches the spilled chloroform and a curtain which whooshes up in flame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jamal!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Run! 66A   EXT. SHACK. NIGHT. They charge past the prone Arvind- a flash of bloodied bandages covering his eyes. 67    EXT. HILLSIDE. NIGHT. Heavy, desperate breathing. Feet stumble on roots. Fall into holes. The three children are running. Branches smack into their faces. But they are so scared, nothing will stop them. Behind them, torches scour the undergrowth. Men shouting. They break out of the woods and are confronted with a train goods yard. 68    EXT. GOODS YARD. NIGHT. They run over the tracks, between the trains, but the shouts are getting louder, the torches closer. A diesel engine is moving out of the station. Jamal, Latika and Salim sprint for the Guard's Van at the very back of the moving train. Punnoose is closest to them. Salim is fastest and first to jump the train. He holds out his hand. Jamal grabs it and is hauled in. Jamal holds his hand out to Latika.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on! Faster! She reaches out to him. Their hands almost touch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take it! Take it! I can't reach...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Salim barges Jamal out of the way. Jamal      stumbles ba as Salim reaches his hand out to Latika,      so he doesn see Latika's hand grasp Salim's, nor see      their eyes lock onto each other, nor see Salim very      deliberatel let go of her hand. Latika stumbles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jamal!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jamal scrambles to the rail. The train gains more speed. Jamal climbs on to the top rung, makes to jump, but Salim flings him backward. Jamal tries to scramble to his feet again, but Salim restrains him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got to go back. We've got to go back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'll kill us if we go back. Jamal! He was going to take your eyes out- with a bloody spoon!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The train is speeding along. Jamal breaks free and stares back at Latika.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She'll be alright. She always is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Latika stumbles again and stops running. They watch as Punnoose catches up with her and stops running. He smashes Latika to the ground. 69   INT. STUDIO. NIGHT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The question was, for two hundred and fifty thousand rupees: who wrote the famous song Chalo Ri Murali. I should warn you, Jamal: from this question on, if you get the answer wrong you lose everything. So. Are you sure? The life-lines are there....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Surdas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Surdas. Apka final jawab?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Computer-ji, A lock kiya-jaye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lights dim, the music swells. Prem presses a button on his computer: looks him straight in the eyes for an age.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (simply) Guess what? You're right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Applause, music, lights. 70   INT. INSPECTOR'S OFFICE. DAY. The Inspector is eying Jamal, weighing it all up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shrugging) Blind singers earn double. You know that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what happened to the girl? They blinded her too?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shakes his head) They had other plans. Though it took me a long, long time to find out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Salim and Jamal are sitting on top of the train. Jamal is staring blankly down the track.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ArГ©, Jamal...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Salim puts an arm around Jamal's shoulder. Jamal wipes the tears from his eyes, shakes his head furiously. Salim gets up. Holds out his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where you going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First class, bhai. Where else?

dialogues.speaker: INT/ EXT. FIRST CLASS CARRIAGE. MORNING.
dialogues.text: The ancient train is huffing slowly up an incline. A middle class Indian couple with their three children are sitting at a table, their breakfast spread before them. Into this domestic scene, unseen by them comes Jamal. Upside down and still outside the train, he is clearly being dangled by his ankles from the train roof. He gives a few, silent directional signs to Salim who manoeuvres him across, dips his hand into the open window, snatches a chapatti and signals franticly to be hoisted up. The family continue to eat, unperturbed. Then Jamal appears again. This time one of the children spots him. Despite Jamal giving her a friendly wave, she yelps. The father of the group grabs Jamal's hand which has just snatched a samosa. There is a tussle, Salim holding onto Jamal's legs, the father holding onto Jamal's arms and Jamal in the middle, shouting. Salim is losing the battle and his footing. He stumbles and the pair of them fall from the train, rolling and tumbling down an embankment in slow-motion. Interspersed with the seemingly endless tumble are images of Jamal and Salim on top of different trains- - huddled together against the freezing rain... - surfing the wind at the front of the train... - admiring the distant Himalaya....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We criss-crossed the country from Rajasthan to Calcutta. Every time we were thrown off we got back on again. This was our home for years. A home with wheels and a whistle. The final tumble as they crash onto flat ground. 73   EXT. RAILWAY EMBANKMENT. DAY. Groggily, Jamal sits up and groans. Somehow in the tumble, he has been transformed into a twelve year-old. And Salim a strong fourteen year-old. Through the haze of pain and dust, Jamal sees something glinting in the distance- something impossibly beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Salim? Is this heaven?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not dead, Jamal. Jamal clears his head. Sees Salim picking himself up from the ground. But the apparition is still there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They stare at the apparition. The unmistakable outline of the Taj Mahal rises from the horizon, pink in the morning sun. Nothing could be more beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some hotel, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jamal and Salim wander under the great dome of the Taj Mahal. Two tiny slum kids dwarfed by this massive monument to love. It is a moment of genuine wonderment for them. Then a tour guide bustles nearby, tourists flowing behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...there are five main elements to the Taj. The Darwaza, the main gateway, the Bageecha or garden, the Masjid or mosque, the Naqqar Khana, the rest house and the Rauza or mausoleum. If you would like to follow me, I will show you the ninety-nine names of Allah on Mumtaz's tomb. As before, please remove your shoes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jamal follows the Guide and his entourage into the mausoleum. Salim meanwhile is studying the line of shoes. Tries a smart pair of women's court shoes, before slipping a foot into a nice, white sneaker. A smile crosses his face. His other foot quickly follows and he saunters away, all mock-innocence.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. TAJ MAHAL. DAY
dialogues.text: Jamal comes out of the mausoleum into the bright sunlight and looks around for Salim. No sign of him. Suddenly, a German couple approach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, what time is the next tour?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Err-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - so much waiting around in this damned country.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Jamal notices that he is standing next to a sign advertising guided tours of the Taj.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - we're on a very tight schedule, you see, young man. Have to see the Red Fort this afternoon. Would it be possible to show us around now? Obviously we understand it would cost more for just the two of us...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter waves a couple of thousand rupee notes at Jamal. His eyes widen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But of course, Madam. Please follow me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jamal stalks off. The Germans follow. Jamal stops before the monument. Points a confident arm at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is....the Taj Mahal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A terrible pause as Peter and Ada stare at him. Clearly more is expected. He moves off at a pace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Taj Mahal was built by the Emperor Khurram for his wife Mumtaz who was maximum beautiful woman in the whole world. When she died, the Emperor decided to build this five star hotel for everyone who wanted to visit her tomb...but he died in- in fifteen eighty-seven, before any of the rooms were built. Or the lifts. The swimming pool, however, as you can see was completed on schedule in top class fashion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He waves confidently in the direction of the fountains.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It says nothing of this in the guide book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With respect, Madam, the guide book is written by a bunch of lazy, good-for-nothing, Indian beggars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And this, Lady and Gentleman, is burial place of Mumtaz.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did she die?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A road traffic accident.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maximum pile-up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suspicious)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought she died in child- birth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nodding sagely)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exactly, Sir. She was on the way to the hospital when it happened. Jamal moves on. Ada and Peter exchange a glance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shrugging)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've seen the way they drive around here... 76   EXT. TAJ MAHAL. DAY. Montage of Jamal authoritatively showing tourists around the Taj Mahal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was the best-paid job I've ever had.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the Princess Diana seat, Madam. Allow me. Jamal shows the tourist a battered postcard of Princess Diana, staring doe-eyed into the distance with the Taj behind. The tourist sits. Jamal adjusts her legs so that they match the postcard. Takes the photo....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tourist police!

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ...and abandons the woman with a polite bow, charging for safety as two Police Officers race towards him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
