dialogues.text: Jamal stands a Tourist on a wall and positions his hands to create the optical illusion that he is dangling the Taj from his fingers. Takes a photo for the Tourist. Behind the Tourist, Salim and a boy called Shankar pick up the Tourist's shoes and saunter casually across the grass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By the side of a busy market street Salim stands next to a row of stolen shoes. Sneakers, court shoes, sandals, high heels...he is busy bartering with a man over a pair whilst Jamal tries to shout up business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Top-class fashion, bottom-class prices! Shoes for all! Shoes for all!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hectares of drying clothes by the side of the river. Spectacular squares of red, saffron, white. Not far away from the dhobi ghat, there is a makeshift slum- camp where Salim and a gang of children are sitting, smoking. Jamal joins them, hands over a wad of rupees to Salim. Salim counts the cash, hands half to Shankar and slaps Jamal so hard on the back that he nearly falls over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And life was good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jamal gets out of a new Mercedes driven by an Indian Man. A middle-aged American couple also get out. Jamal points them down a lane which opens out on India's largest dhobi where hundreds of women are beating clothes on stone slabs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the biggest dhobi ghat in the whole of India, Mister David.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They say that every man in Uttar Pradesh is wearing a kurta that has been washed here at least one time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that so? That's amazing. Let's get a look at this, Adele.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gets out his video camera and wanders towards the dhobi ghat. Behind them a motor rickshaw pulls up. Salim, Shankar and a couple of the street kids from the Taj leap out. Within seconds, the Mercedes is up on bricks and the wheels are being removed. Salim takes a hacksaw to the Mercedes badge on the bonnet, whilst urging the others on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ArГ©, sala! Formula One, Formula One! Pit-stop ka speed, Schumacher ka ishtyle

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crowds in the lane barely notice as the car is stripped of all its parts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go, go!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A shout from the top of the lane and the boys scatter, bouncing the four wheels at speed down the lane. Jamal, the Indian driver and the two Americans return. They stop in front of the denuded car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Woah. What happened here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly the Indian driver is slapping Jamal ferociously around the head with one of his shoes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I give you two tight slaps, mader chod!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know! I didn't do it, did I...? Nothing to do with me...get off!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But the beating continues, the driver kicking Jamal down onto the floor. The two Americans stare, uncertain what to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do something, Clark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I- I dunno, I-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finally Clark intervenes, pulling the driver off Jamal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, okay, just cool it. You're insured, aren't you? Jesus Christ... Jamal sits up. He is bleeding from his nose and mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wanted to see the `real India', Mister David. Here it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, here's a bit of the real America, too, son. Adele pulls out his wallet and rummages for dollars. 81   EXT. YAMUNA RIVER. NIGHT. A battered Jamal limps along the river bank towards the Taj. He stops, bathes his swollen face in the river. Then looks up. Strange lights appear to emanate from the base of the monument. And then strange sounds. 82   EXT. TAJ MAHAL. NIGHT. Jamal climbs   a crumbling   wall and is confronted with opera taking   place right   under the dome. Gluck's Orfe ed Euridice.   Hundreds of   India's smartest professiona are watching   from banked   seating on a scaffolding frame. 83   EXT. STANDS. NIGHT. Jamal and a couple of street kids slip under the scaffolding supporting the banked seats. The street kids are trying to reach the hand-bags of the women above them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hissing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oi, Jamal! There's a woman with no panties on over here. Jamal reaches up and easily lifts a wallet from a man's trouser pocket. On stage, the actors start singing. Jamal seems to have forgotten the wallet and stares, mesmerised, at the stage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you put it back and listen to the music?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Jamal starts, makes to run, but the woman who spoke holds out a cigarette. A Canadian back-packer is sitting, staring at the singers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's called Orfeo. Orpheus and Eurydice. Orpheus- that one there- is looking for his lover, Eurydice. She died, but he can't live without her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hands him a cigarette. He puts the wallet back. She smiles at him and they both turn to the stage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The pain is so bad that he goes to the underworld- the place we go when we die- to try to get her back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't do that. Can you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shrugging) You can in opera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does he find her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watch and see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jamal watches as Orpheus sings one of the most beautiful pieces of music a human is likely to hear. Tears are running down Jamal's cheeks. 84   EXT. YAMUNA RIVER. NIGHT. Salim, Shankar, Jamal and the Taj Gang are gathered around a campfire. All of them wear extraordinary foot- wear of one form or another, from elaborate high heels to walking boots five sizes too large. A home-made hooka pipe is being passed around the fire. The eyes of the children have long since stopped focussing. Salim is sporting a Mercedes Benz badge on a chain around his neck. Behind him, Jamal appears, his face swollen. He takes off his fake Guide's Badge and throws it in the fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Woah! What are you- Jamal?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have to go, Salim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go? Go where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bombay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be stupid. We're making good money here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We should have gone a long time ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Salim turns to Shankar with sudden understanding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, God. Baby brother's in love. With a flat-chested hijra.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Latika was one of us. A musketeer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A musketeer...Grow up, Jamal. Look, how was I to know they'd beat you up. Here, you can have some of the cash. Come on...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got cash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He rips out a wad of dollar bills from his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enough. I'm getting my stuff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait! Jamal! Ah, shit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gets up, kicks the fire in rage and stomps after Jamal. 85   INT. STUDIO. NIGHT. Prem leans back in his chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, my friend: ready for another question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prem presses his computer. The lights dim again, the music comes up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For a straight one million rupees, Ladies and Gentlemen...On an American One Hundred Dollar Bill there is a portrait of which American statesman? Is it A), George Washington, B) Franklin Roosevelt, C) Benjamin Franklin, D) Abraham Lincoln?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence from Jamal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pay or play, Jamal? All you have to do is stop now and you walk away with a cool quarter of a million rupees. Decide to play, get the answer wrong and you walk away with absolutely nothing. But, get the answer right and you win a million rupees. So. You decide. Pay or play?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A long pause. 86   INT. GALLERY. NIGHT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, he hasn't got a clue. This is going to be a walk-away. Stand by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, he's going to play with him, first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get a lot of hundred dollar bills in your line of work, Jamal?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The minimum tip for my services.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laughter from the audience.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now I know why my cell phone bill is so high...they pay the chi-wallah in hundred dollar bills!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's C. Benjamin Franklin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A gasp from the audience. Prem is caught off-guard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Woah! We haven't locked the computer, man. You're going to play?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I just have. Haven't I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You certainly have. C. Right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right. C.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not confusing your Franklins? Benjamin for Roosevelt?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've never heard of Roosevelt Franklin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a million rupees at stake and he's never heard of Roosevelt Franklin...I can't bear to look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gives this one to the audience who titter on cue. Jamal looks confused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no. Don't you worry, Jamal. You were asked which statesman is depicted on a hundred dollar bill. You said C. Benjamin Franklin. Ladies and Gentlemen...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He presses the computer, pretends to ruminate for a while with his finger pressed to his lips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jamal Malik- you chose to play not pay. I'm afraid you no longer have two hundred and fifty thousand rupees....

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Prem leans over and tears up the cheque. There is a sigh of disappointment from the audience, a look of confusion on Jamal's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...you in fact have one million rupees! Wild applause from the audience. Jamal allows himself a genuine smile. 88   INT. INSPECTOR'S OFFICE. DAY. The Inspector pulls out a note from his wallet. Glances at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's on the thousand rupee note?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. He waves the note at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Gandhi!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've heard of him. The Inspector kicks his chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't get clever or I'll get the electricity out again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They didn't ask me that question. I don't know why. Ask them. The Inspector stares hard at Jamal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Funny, you don't seem that interested in money. Then, Constable Srinivas stomps back into the office, sweat pouring from him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Platform Seventeen- Has to consult his notebook.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A statue of Frederick Stevens, architect and builder of Victoria Terminus in -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - yes, yes, Srinivas. The hundred dollar bill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From a thousand feet in the sky, looking down on the limitless megatropolis of Mumbai. Half-built sky- scrapers, slums, factories, roads, trains.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bombay had turned into Mumbai.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We descend, down until the lines of ants become people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The orphanage had gone, the slum had gone, the people.... all gone. And everywhere was building, building, building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Descending even further, we pick out a construction site and then Jamal.... 90   EXT. CONSTRUCTION SITE. DAY. ..who is staring through a wire fence at the construction site.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I knew she was here. Somewhere she was here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns away, then something catches his eye. Underneath all the scraps of flyers and posters on a broken wall is a corner of something that Jamal recognises. He tears back a poster. Underneath, faded but recognisable is one of their beanbag graffiti advertisements. 91   EXT. SLUM. NIGHT. Jamal asks a group of stall-holders on the slum main street. They shrug, aren't interested. The camera pulls up and up until Jamal is nothing but a dot wandering the maze of lanes, railways and highways, one among endless millions of people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evenings, I searched. Days, I worked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jamal wanders up to the rickshaw drivers parked outside the hotel. He stops and asks a question. The drivers shake their heads. Jamal continues up the steps towards a door, exhausted face and grubby clothes walking straight towards camera. He goes through the door and immediately.... 93   INT. HOTEL. FOYER. DAY. ....is, without breaking step in a slightly grubby white uniform. He walks across the echoing, marble floor of a struggling four-star hotel, goes through double doors.... 94   INT. HOTEL CORRIDOR. DAY. ...into a corridor that is devoid of carpet, paint- anything except a phone on the bare wall and a stool. The phone is ringing. Jamal sits on the stool and answers the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Room service, good afternoon?... Yes, sir. Two chicken burgers, two fries, one cocoa-cola and one mango lassi and a large bottle of mineral water...Bisleri or Himalayan Spring, Sir?...Certainly, Sir. That will be with you in fifteen minutes, Sir. Thank you. Have a nice day. He hangs up and goes through another set of doors... 95   INT. HOTEL KITCHENS. DAY. ...to a cramped kitchen with definite hygiene problems. The cooks are playing carom on the table while under it Salim is dozing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two chicken burgers, coke, mango lassi and a bottle of Bisleri. Dozily, Salim gets up and takes a look behind one of the fridges. He chases out a chicken with a desultory kick and sorts through some empty mineral water bottles until he finds a Bisleri bottle. Salim fills the bottle of mineral water from the tap and begins delicately re- sealing the tamper-proof lid with super-glue. Jamal collects cutlery and starts laying out a tray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to Chowpatti again, okay? Want to come?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For God's sake. You got some disease? You force me back to this shit-hole, we leave our friends, a good life, loads of money- for this. Isn't that enough?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We came back to find her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, you did, Jamal, not me. Me, I don't give a shit about her. Plenty of pussy in Bombay for Salim. Oh, yes, sir! You should come down the Cages on Saturday night instead of searching for your lost love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to Chowpatti.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (impersonating Ram) "I'm going to Chowpatti". There are nineteen million people in this city, Jamal. Forget her. She's history.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But she wasn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jamal is dodging the traffic at a busy junction. He moves around the beggars who are working the cars. Then he hears singing. He looks around, suddenly panicked. It is a siren song drawing him across the road, not even noticing that he is narrowly run down by a couple of cars, to a traffic island underneath a flyover. He turns a corner and there is the singer, leaning up against one of the struts of the flyover. Arvind. Older now, just like Jamal, a fourteen year-old boy. But eye- less. Jamal freezes. He approaches Arvind and waits until he has finished singing. Despite his eyeless sockets, Arvind appears to know somebody is there. He turns and bows low, putting his hands together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Namaste, Sahib. Any kindness you give will be repaid in heaven many times.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Jamal gets a couple of notes out of his pocket and puts them into Arvind's outstretched hand. He feels the notes with his fingers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A fifty. And a hundred! Blessings upon you, Sahib.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are many ways of seeing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arvind puts his hands together and bows deep again. Then, Jamal takes his shoe off and gets out a hundred dollar bill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jamal crouches down and puts the bill into Arvind's hand. His fingers feel it. He sniffs it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dollars. But how many?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One hundred.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now you are playing with me, Sahib.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I swear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is on it? The pictures. Tell me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A building. With a clock on it. Trees behind it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The other side. Turn it over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man- it doesn't say his name. He is sort of bald, but has long hair on the sides.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) Benjamin Franklin. My God, my God. Thank you, Sahib. You were generous the first time. But this...

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He stops. Suspects.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And without even a song? A long pause. Arvind keeps hold of Jamal's arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you are rich, now, are you, Jamal? I am happy for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am so sorry, Arvind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got away. I didn't. That is all. No, no tears. Tears mock me all the more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arvind, I am looking for-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - how's your voice, Jamal?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. I haven't sung since- since then. Arvind, I-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - and your eyes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (surprised)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My eyes? My eyes are fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then stay away, chutiyГ©, and count your blessings every morning you open them and see the sun rising. You owe Maman. He doesn't forget.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I owe Latika. Arvind shakes his head angrily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please. Is she alive? Arvind, is she alive?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alive? Oh, she's alive alright. It's your life, Jamal. Pila Street. They call her Cherry, now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. Jamal heads off through the traffic. Arvind shouts after him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will sing at your funeral, yaar. 97   EXT. PILA STREET. NIGHT. Dark, crowded streets. Gangs of women stand outside the doorways or lean out of upstairs windows. They are garishly-dressed prostitutes varying in age from 13 to 60. Men wander past, eying the possibilities, exchanging lewd comments with them. Among the hordes on the pavement are Jamal and Salim. They pass doorway after doorway of narrow rooms where prostitutes wait for customers. Jamal and Salim stop at each group of women, Salim taking the lead, clearly asking them something, as the women either shrug or offer them something lewd- judging by the laughter that follows. But one woman in a narrow doorway points down the street. Jamal has to drag a reluctant Salim away from the group. 98   INT. BROTHEL. NIGHT. They go into one of the tiny houses. Loud Filmi music comes from upstairs. They are confronted by a woman in her fifties watching tv. She is less than interested.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm looking for Cherry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, kid. Not available. Plenty of others. Take a look. She indicates curtained cubicles behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Latika's brother. The Woman looks at him properly for the first time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's still not on the menu. Choose someone else or piss off. Then, Jamal pulls out some rupee notes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just two minutes to talk to her. She takes the money, counts it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She nods upwards. Salim and Jamal head up the dark, tiny staircase. The Woman picks up the phone on her desk. 99    INT. LANDING. NIGHT. On the tiny landing, Salim and Jamal pull back a curtain to reveal a humping couple. They move on, past more women lying on their beds or blankly having sex, not in the least perturbed to be interrupted. They reach the end of the landing. From the other side of the door comes the filmi music. Jamal puts his eye to one of the gaps in the slatted door. Through it he can see glimpses of a girl dancing to the music. Latika; though not the rag-picker of before. Now fifteen, she is a beautiful young woman and dressed in a revealing, turquoise, silk sari.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it her or not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shoves Jamal out of the way and watches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit, she's sexy, man....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then the music stops, an effeminate man steps into the limited frame Salim can see and snaps a stick down hard on Latika's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smile! Flow, flow! You entice with the hands not make chapattis, you gawaar. Again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man starts the music again and Latika's hands flow elegantly around her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lift your feet, you lump. Stop, stop!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The stick is raised to hit her but Jamal opens the door. 100   INT. BROTHEL. NIGHT. She can barely believe her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jamal?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Dance Teacher turns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell do you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He switches off the music.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come. Quick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Latika remains fixed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You silly little boys. Get out now while you can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come with us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Latika runs to Jamal. But she freezes as she looks at the doorway. Maman, Punnoose and the Woman from downstairs stand there. The skin around Punnoose's eye bears the blisters from the chloroform burn years ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look who we have here, Punnoose. Hello again, Jamal. Salim. Never forget a face. Especially one that I own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shall I take them to the marshes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatever you like. Have fun. Just make sure that you dispose of them properly afterwards. No traces, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns to Jamal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You really thought you could just walk in and take my prize away? Have you any idea how much this little virgin is worth, bhen chod?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He fingers Latika's hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get them out of here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Punnoose and the Muscle walk towards Jamal. Maman turns to the Dance Teacher as they grab his arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please continue, Master-ji.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Dance Teacher puts the music back on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Suddenly, Salim is holding a pistol.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leave him. Get over there. Punnoose and the Muscle slowly release Jamal and join Maman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's not be foolish, Salim. Heavy, aren't they? Salim straightens up his gun arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can have money. Here. Maman gets out his wallet and throws all the money in it on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take it. Go. Disappear with your friend and we'll forget all about this. Okay? Salim collects up the money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maman never forgets. Isn't that right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Maman can make an exception. Salim walks over to the music, turns it up. Picks up a cushion from the bed and walks right up to Maman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't take that risk, Maman. Sorry. He wraps the cushion around the gun and pulls the trigger. Or tries to. Nothing happens. There is a frozen moment as they watch him fail to shoot. Everybody watches with surreal interest as Salim fumbles with the pistol. Eventually he looks up, giggles stupidly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Safety catch. Shrugs apologetically and shoots. Nobody is more surprised than Maman who crumples onto the floor.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Latika starts desperately gathering up the notes on the floor, grabs Maman's wallet. Jamal just stands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on. They run out of the room and down the stairs as Maman dies on the floor in front of his frozen colleagues. 101   EXT. CHOWPATTY BEACH. DUSK. Children are splashing in the sea, flying kites, digging sand, laughing. Salim, Latika and Jamal are crouched on the shore watching the sun sink into the sea. Latika is going through Maman's wallet, Salim is fingering the pistol, admiringly. Jamal is staring out to sea. Each in their own world, yet sharing swigs from a bottle of Johnny Walker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit, there's thousands here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We should be celebrating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You just killed somebody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was going to kill us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where did you get the gun?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bought it. Now, I'm going to have to throw this beauty in the sea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't need to kill him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? Typical. I save your life and you're on at me. All you ever do is mess us up. Whenever you're around-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - shut up, can't you? Just shut up. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why can't you just be happy, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Happy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got what you wanted, didn't you? So, let's celebrate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Let's celebrate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She takes a long swig from the bottle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: While we can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She nudges Jamal and holds the bottle out to him. Smiles at him. He smiles back, shakes the black dog from his head and takes a long, long drink. Latika and Salim cheer. 101A   EXT. TULIP STAR. NIGHT. Latika, Salim and Jamal bend back a bit of the wire mesh fence that protects the deserted hotel. Crawl in. 102    INT. TULIP STAR. LOBBY. NIGHT. A very wobbly Latika, Salim and Jamal walk up the frozen escalators of the empty hotel, lit only by security lights. Kick through the odd pile of rubbish and stacked-up chairs. Go to the dusty reception desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Service!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reception!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We want a room, boy. Executive Class with smoking. Third floor with balcony.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sea-facing, yaar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have the bags brought up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And they scoot off, giggling into the dark. 102A   INT. TULIP STAR. KITCHENS. NIGHT. Jamal and Latika wander the vast, empty kitchens. Jamal searches the empty chillers and cabinets. Then, realises that he is alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Latika? Salim?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are they? Suddenly,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Room service!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She comes shooting out of the darkness across the kitchen floor riding a trolley with Salim pushing her at top speed. Jamal has to skid out of the way. He grabs another trolley and glides off in pursuit. 102B   INT. TULIP STAR. CORRIDOR. NIGHT. The three stand by a mirror and play with their reflections. 102C   INT. TULIP STAR. HOTEL LOBBY. LATER. On top of the metal preparation counters, Salim and Jamal are fencing: Jamal with a fish slice and Salim with a large spoon. 103    INT. HOTEL ROOM. NIGHT. An empty, dusty hotel suite. Jamal is on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 307 here. I want a bottle of Johnny Walker Red Label, beer, wine-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - chicken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah! Chicken....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jamal closes his eyes at the wonderful thought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of chicken?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (also dreaming) Tikka Masala. With roti-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naan, chutney, dal-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - aloo gobi, rice-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stops. Change of mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pop Tarts!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold the line, chutiye. Pop Tarts?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the tv. The commercial. Everybody's happy when they have Pop Tarts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exactly! A bucket of Pop Tarts, chutiye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jamal slams down the phone. 104   INT. HOTEL ROOM. LATER. Latika is clearly in the shower. Jamal wanders in carrying an old pair of lunghi. Shouts through the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Found some lunghi!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stay there. Look away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The shower stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Atcha, atcha.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll know if you're looking....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a towel around her, Latika comes to the doorway where Jamal is holding out a the lunghi with his eyes tight shut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's Salim?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dunno.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She watches this innocent a second with true fondness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a sweet boy, Jamal.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She takes the lunghi from his outstretched hand and disappears into the bathroom, slamming the door with a giggle. 105   EXT. MUMBAI SLUM STREET. NIGHT. Salim wanders the crowded streets of a slum. He stops uncertainly at a doorway where a group of men are lolling, smoking. Plucks up his courage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm looking for Javed-bhai.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ja, mada chod. He's not looking for you. Ja!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need to see him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The group of men stir, irritated now. Salim begins to back away, then stops. Pulls the gun from behind his back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I killed Maman. I'll kill you too. Easy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The group are frozen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You killed him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Javed is standing in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My enemy's enemy is my friend, no? So, come in, friend.

dialogues.speaker: INT. HOTEL ROOM. LATER.
dialogues.text: Jamal and Latika lie on the bed, drunk, though still coherent. Latika is dressed in the Bell-Boy's jacket and the old lunghi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maman's gang will hunt us. You know that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't care.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me neither.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They burst into stupid laughter. The laughter subsides.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That dance you were doing. In Pila Street. Show me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Latika rolls over and switches off the light. Rolls back. In the half light, her hands begin to move for Jamal, the elegant, alluring hand movements of the bar- girl dancers. Jamal stares, mesmerised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You came back for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you'd forgotten.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never forgot. Not for one day. I knew I'd find you in the end. It's our destiny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Destiny. Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Latika stops her hands. They stare at each other, their faces inches away from each other. Latika strokes Jamal's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And face to face, they slowly fall asleep. 107   INT. HOTEL ROOM. LATER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jamal opens his eyes. Salim is standing over them, swaying with alcohol.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Salim?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He puts his hand out to Latika.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Salim....Bhai, you've had a lot to drink...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jamal tries to get up, but Salim's hand is round his throat and pushes him down on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am the elder. And I am the boss. For once, you do as I say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Salim pulls Latika to her feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saved your bloody life, didn't I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Salim, please-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - chup, sali.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he turns, pulling a protesting Latika, Jamal leaps on him. The two brothers go down fighting, but of course it is Salim who comes up on top. Latika launches herself at Salim, but he smashes her away, almost delighted that she has joined in. He drags Jamal to the door, laughing. 108   INT. HOTEL CORRIDOR. NIGHT. Salim throws him out into the corridor, slams the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am Number One now!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Salim, no, no....!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get yourself a room, bhai.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Salim slams the door. Jamal gets up, bangs on the door, keeps on banging until the door opens and Salim stands there with the pistol pointing straight at Jamal's head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man with the Colt 45 says chup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shoves Jamal hard down the corridor, the gun pointed at him all the while.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Salim...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Salim nods towards the fire escape door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now go. Or Gunmaster G-9 will shoot you right between the eyes. Boom. Don't think he won't. You have five seconds. One, two, three, four-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Salim cocks the pistol. Jamal screws up his eyes for the inevitable. But Salim shoves him out with a roar and slams the door. Jamal bangs on the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Salim...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Salim walks slowly back down the corridor as Jamal bangs and bangs on the door. Down the hall, Salim's door shuts. 109   INT. INSPECTOR'S OFFICE. DAY. The Inspector is staring hard at Jamal. Srinivas is desperately trying to get his attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, sir!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (eventually) Enlighten us Constable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Accessory to murder, Sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Inspector puts his hands in the air, palms up. Simple.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only the finest minds in the Mumbai Police Force.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Untroubled by irony, Srinivas looks extremely pleased.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go check the files, Constable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Srinivas goes out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You puzzle me, Slumdog. Admitting murder to avoid a charge of fraud is not exactly clever thinking. Now, why would you do that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jamal shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When somebody asks me a question, I tell them the answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the gate, a Security Guard is sitting in his chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Guard grunts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where did they go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A more impatient grunt from the Guard. He stands up, walks towards Jamal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, Sir. Which way?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know and I don't care.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Guard raises his stick and gives him a roar. Jamal backs away onto the street. The Guard slams the gate shut. Jamal looks despairingly up and down the street at the teeming traffic, the crowds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ready for another question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. I'm ready.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are back in the Studio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For two and a half million rupees. Ladies and Gentlemen. Cambridge Circus is in which UK City. Is it A) Oxford, B) Leeds, C) Cambridge, D) London.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jamal smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's smiling. Why does that worry me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leaden skies. Torrential rain is hammering on the tin roofs of the slum. 114   INT. SHACK. DAY. Eighteen year-old Jamal's eyes open. Now with the beginnings of a beard and moustache, Jamal wakes in a tiny shack just big enough for a mattress on the floor. He pulls on a shirt, lifts the mattress and takes out his trousers which have been pressing there all night, puts them over his shoulder, picks up his shoes and goes down a ladder. 115   INT. SHACK. DAY. He descends into a room and two feet of water that is eddying around the ground floor of the shack. Wades out of the door into the narrow lane of the slum. 116   EXT. SLUM. DAY. Jamal nods hello to a number of neighbours, also bare- legged, also with their shoes in hand. Together, they wade to higher ground, put on their trousers and shoes and trudge up to the main road. 117   INT. CALL CENTRE. NIGHT. Ultra-modern, glass-windowed office. The words Cultural Studies are written on the white board. Jamal walks in with a tray of glasses of chi. He puts a glass down on the young, hip, Teacher's desk and heads out again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, guys, it's been a big week in UK. Kat is back. He holds up a copy of Radio Times showing Kat from East Enders smiling at them. A collective groan from the Trainees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's already back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bardi...Jamal?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Well. She did come back, then she went away when Alfie split up with her and now she's back again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it looks as if Alfie still fancies Mo after all, so-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - thank you, Jamal. Keep up, Bardi. The chi-wallah knows more than you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bardi glares at Jamal. Jamal shrugs apologetically and goes out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, it's been super-duper hot for UK this week, so there'll be a lot of chat about that- they love their weather- and there's the festival in Edinburgh- Edinburgh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He points at a young woman Trainee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scotland. Kilts, castles, err, haggis? Porridge, the Highlands, mountains. Ben- Ben Nevis?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Teacher points at another Trainee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Detective Taggart. Whisky, Sean Connery!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And lochs. Their word for lakes. Good. It's also double bonus time for an upgrade to the `friends and family' package this week, so remember to push for an upgrade...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Every Call!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jamal walks out, turns a corner. 118   INT. CALL CENTRE. UK FLOOR. NIGHT. We are confronted with a room you could swing a Boeing in. Rows and rows of Operators in tiny booths stretch into the distance. On the walls are pictures of London, Tony Blair, red telephone boxes, the Yorkshire Dales, the Highlands- a snapshot of tourist Britain. Huge posters of soap stars and celebrities adorn the rest of the walls. Slogans hang from the ceiling. "When the sun comes up, you'd better be running", "you snooze, you lose", "Upgrade for a better, faster life." "Every call is a new opportunity".

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Each section of the room has a banner with a British city's name on it and various mock sign-posts for the different aisles. A Manager under the banner "Bradford", is standing over an Operator, listening in on a call. The Manager leans over and presses a key.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If they want an upgrade, a new tariff or we're stealing them from the other networks, you take the call. Anything else-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He mimes cutting his throat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No time-wasters on Team Bradford, kid. Leave that to the homosexuals on Tunbridge Wells.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jamal stops by him. The Manager takes a glass of tea from Jamal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where've you been? Dave on Cornmarket's virtually lost his voice, there's two on Ilkley Moor who've had their hands up for hours. Come on, move it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jamal hurries down the aisle signposted "Cornmarket", gets to a male trainee and hands him a tea. Dave glances around to check nobody's looking and slips off his head-set.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two minutes, Jamal. I'm on "Millionaire" duty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rajneesh...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's my turn, Jamal. I've had my pee breaks. Please. If he comes just keep your head down and pretend you're doing an upgrade on the-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - `friends and family'. I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jamal still looks unwilling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two minutes.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Dave heads off towards a Rest and Recreation room, where a big plasma screen on the wall is showing "Who Wants To Be A Millionaire."Jamal grabs the jacket from the back of Dave's chair, puts the head-set on and hunches over the booth, just another Operative at work. We become aware that every operator down the Cornmarket aisle- and quite a few other aisles besides- is staring in the direction of the Rest and Recreation Room. 119   INT. REST AND RECREATION ROOM. NIGHT. Dave is watching the screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...if you want a chance to be a contestant on Who Wants To Be A Millionaire, dial the number now. Dave dives for the doorway and waves. 120   INT. CALL CENTRE. UK FLOOR. NIGHT. Suddenly all the operators are dialling. Almost simultaneously, twenty or so voices say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like to be a contestant on Who Wants to be a Millionaire. Most of the Operators- including the man next to Jamal- suddenly lose their tension.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bloody bastard. I never get it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have to dial when Prem says "if". "If you want the chance to be a contestant on Who Wants To Be A Millionaire..." That's when they open the lines. The Operator looks at him. Jamal shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what Anjum in Technical says. He put the system in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So why don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello? Hello? Have I been transferred again, for God's sake?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Jamal freezes with fear. The head-set speaks again with its broad Scottish accent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello? Jesus, God, will somebody talk to me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Mrs...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stares at the computer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Mackintosh from King Gussie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (weary) It's Kingussie, love. Pronounced Kinoosie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kinoosie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So where are you from? Abroad, I bet. China or somewhere. What good is-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - just down the road from your house, Mrs Mackintosh. Next to the loch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suspicious) Oh aye? Which loch?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jamal searches desperately around, spots a picture of Big Ben.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loch Big- Loch Ben. Next door to Detective Taggart's flat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loch Ben? Och, no, hen, that's one of the wee ones up in the Highlands. You're all the way up there? But I bet it rains, eh, hen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indeed yes, Mrs Mackintosh. I have to wade through a metre of water every morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, yes, Mrs Mackintosh. In my kilt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Och, no, hen. Jamal puts his feet on the desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's alright once I've had my porridge, my haggis and a few Scotch whiskies- and the monsoon's nearly over, so-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - and what monsoon would that be? I'd like to speak to your supervisor, son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think that's a good idea. He is a very important man, Mrs Mackintosh-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - get me the supervisor on this line now-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - and he doesn't like bloody time wasters. Jamal panics, presses the button he saw the Manager press earlier. The screen goes blank, then reboots itself. Jamal looks around. Where the hell is Dave? On the screen, Jamal is faced with the question: "what name do you require?" He looks around again, and then with one finger types in the word "Latika". He presses enter. Hundred upon hundred of Latikas with their surnames and phone numbers scroll down the page. He erases her name and enters the name Salim K. Malik. Presses enter. Fifteen numbers come up. He stares at the numbers for a long time, then types it into his computer and presses dial.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Salim?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who wants to know? Do you know what bloody time it is? Clearly not Jamal's brother. Jamal cuts the line. Dials the next number.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh. Hello? Clearly not his Salim. He cuts the line. Dials again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello? Hello? Who is this? But Jamal can't speak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey. Is someone screwing with me? Silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am calling from XL 5 Communications Sir. As a valued customer, we are offering you a free upgrade with our `friends and- Jamal's voice peters out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jamal? Is that you? Brother? Where are you, man?...I thought you were dead or something...we had to go, Jamal. Maman's guys. They were searching the hotel...Jamal, say something. Please. There is another long silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Salim. 121   INT. STUDIO. NIGHT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ever been to Cambridge?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ever been to the circus?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. And I've never been to UK before. But I'll still have a go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gasps and laughter from the audience. Jamal laughs and shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prem grips his heart theatrically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can someone call me an ambulance?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A flash of a sign post reading `Oxford Circus', pointing down one of the aisles. The banner above that section of the warehouse reads `London'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jamal hurrying down another `Kings Parade' carrying glasses of tea. He glances up to see a large banner that says `Cambridge'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jamal comes back up an aisle named `Broad Street'. An Operator on the adjacent `The High' clicks his fingers for another cup. Jamal hurries under the sign marked `Oxford'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The signposts of the aisles come faster and faster `Pembroke Street', `Trafalgar Square', `East India Dock' and finally `Cambridge Circus'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, Jamal....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jamal is sweating, his face scrunched up in thought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't remember.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't remember. Does that mean you did know? Once?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think it's Oxford.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Based on your extensive travelling, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (almost to himself) Well, Oxford has Broad Street, Saint Aldates, Turl Street, Queen Street, The High and Magdalene Bridge- which is pronounced Maudlin, so-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stops as he hears the surprised laughter of the audience.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you hadn't been to UK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I haven't. And it's not Leeds, because that's Elland Road, Kirkgate Market, Commercial Street, St Peter's-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (icy) - what might it be then, Jamal?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I don't think it's Cambridge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cambridge Circus is not in Cambridge? Dare I ask why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too obvious. There's definitely an Oxford Circus in London, and there's a rowing race between Oxford and Cambridge so there's probably a Cambridge Circus too. I'll go for D) London.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the logic that's got him this far, Ladies and Gentlemen. Who are we to argue? So. Jamal. D. Apka final jawab?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shrugs) If the Gods are with me...Final answer. D.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The lights dim, the music swells as Prem pushes the button on his computer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Computer-ji, D lock kiya-jaye. More portentous music.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's been a rollercoaster ride all the way, a pleasure to have you on the show, my friend, but I'm sorry to say that you're....incredibly, absolutely right! Huge cheers and applause. Even Jamal laughs at this. He cannot quite believe it himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ladies and Gentlemen, Jamal Malik, the man with two and a half million rupees! More applause. Prem hands him a cheque. Jamal looks at it. Laughs again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few hours ago, you were fetching tea for the phone- wallahs. Now you are richer than they ever will ever be. What a player, Ladies and Gentleman! What a player. The lights dim, the music swells. Prem consults his computer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For five million rupees, my friend: who invented the revolver? Was it A) Samuel Colt, B) Bruce Browning, C Dan Wesson or D) James Revolver? Dramatic pause. 124   INT. HOTEL. NIGHT. A flash of Salim shooting Maman. Another flash of Salim in the doorway, holding the pistol up to Jamal's head. 125   INT. STUDIO. NIGHT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suddenly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A). Samuel Colt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A). Samuel Colt. Are you sure?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jamal nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Final answer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Final answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The music swells again. Prem presses his computer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You had two and a half million rupees. If I may-?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He holds out his hand. Jamal hands him back the cheque. He tears the cheque in two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ladies and Gentlemen, the chi- wallah has done it again! D. Is right! Incredible!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cheers and applause from the audience. 125A   INT. INSPECTOR'S OFFICE. NIGHT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not that incredible. You'd just murdered somebody with a Colt 45, after all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was self-defence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's call it manslaughter, then, shall we?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Getting hot in here, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (genuinely) Are you nervous?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The audience laugh. Prem is momentarily flustered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? Am I nervous? You're the one who's in the hot seat, my friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Yes. Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More laughter. 127   INT. GALLERY. NIGHT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bloody hell. He's got Prem on the run...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Music, lights. Prem presses his computer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What sports do you play?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: None.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: None. Oh, dear, oh dear, oh dear. Not to worry, there's only ten million rupees at stake... Which cricketer has scored the most first class centuries in history. Was it A) Sachin Tendulkar, B) Ricky Ponting, C) Michael Slater, D) Jack Hobbs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prem allows the question to sink in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've got a cheque for five million rupees in your hands. You've still got two life-lines, Phone A Friend and 50/50. For ten million rupees: pay, play, or bail out. It's still an option. Remember, if you get the answer wrong, you will lose everything like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He clicks his fingers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you sure you want to do this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An Indian batsman hits a nicely-timed stroke, heads down the wicket for a single. Turns. The other batsman is taking a second run.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The Indian tries to halt the other batsman with a shout, then succumbs to the inevitable and charges down the wicket. A fielder hurls the ball at the stumps. The bails fly off. 130   INT. STUDIO. NIGHT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll play.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tense laughter from the audience. Prem holds up the cheque. Jamal nods. Prem tears it up slowly. Allows the pieces to fall to the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dreams of so many. On the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jamal is riding the construction lift to the top of a high building, still just a shell but buzzing with carpenters, bricklayers, cable-layers. The lift stops at the top. Jamal gets out. Looks around. He is miles up. Alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jamal!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jamal looks around. There is Salim standing on the edge of the building. He saunters over to Jamal, his arms outstretched in theatrical greeting. He is groomed, expensively dressed with the best mobile money can buy dangling from a gold chain around his neck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God is good, bhai. God is good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He tries to embrace Jamal. With as much force as he can muster, Jamal punches him in the face. Salim takes it. Stands there. Wipes blood from his lip. Gets another punch. Then another and another, not even defending himself, until he is being beaten back by a raging Jamal towards the edge of the building. Finally, he tries to reason with Jamal

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maman's boys were after us. Had to skip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jamal keeps on beating him back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Liar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Left a message at reception. Waited weeks for you in Nagpur.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There was no message at reception.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bhai, I left a message.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Salim opens his arms, defenceless. It would take one, small push to send him over the edge. There is a moment, when Jamal might. He even has his hands on his chest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will never forgive you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The fury in Jamal subsides minutely. Finally, he turns away with a roar of frustration. Salim hangs his head. 131A   EXT. TOWER BLOCK. LATER. Jamal and Salim are sitting on the very edge of the building. They can see for miles across the city. Salim has rediscovered his attitude.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you believe it? This was our slum. We lived just there, huh? Now it is business, apartments, call centres...Fuck USA, fuck China. India is at the centre of the world, now, bhai. And I am at the centre of the centre, Jamal. This is all Javed-bhai's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Javed Mehta? The Gangster from our slum? You work for him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who else would protect us from Maman's gang, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you do for him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anything he asks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Salim's mobile rings. Salim is immediately subservient on the phone. Rings off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is coming. You must go. My card.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hands Jamal a card.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think I am going to let you out of my sight again, little brother? You stay with me now. Ab phut!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Salim, where's Latika?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still? She's gone, Jamal. Long gone. Now go. Quick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jamal gets up, hurries away, hidden behind piles of building materials just as Javed appears in his flash suit and jewelry. Three of his young henchmen walk alongside. 132    INT. SALIM'S APARTMENT.    NIGHT. Jamal is asleep on a mattress on the floor of a smart apartment. A mobile phone rings. The muffled sound of Salim talking quietly next door. Then, Salim creeps into the room, checks to see Jamal is asleep, unlocks a desk drawer and brings out his pistol. He puts it in a hold-all and goes out the front door. Jamal's eyes snap open. He has seen it all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slum dogs never sleep, only nap. He would disappear for a couple of days and come back changed. Sometimes elated-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door bangs open and a giggling-drunk, half-naked Bar Girl drags the sleeping Jamal up and into the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He has flipped! I can't do anything with him....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Salim is in the bath, bathing, literally, in money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at it, bhai, look at it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes the opposite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jamal creeps towards Salim's bedroom door. He pushes it open a fraction to see Salim crouched on the floor in prayer, sobbing quietly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispering) AГ© khuda mujhГ© baksh dГ© mainГ© bahut gunaah kiyГ© hain....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But younger brothers don't interfere. Mostly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Salim comes out of his apartment block. Gets into his jeep. Drives off. Doesn't notice Jamal in the motor rickshaw that pulls out and follows him. 136   EXT. JAVED'S BUNGALOW. DAY. Salim approaches a gate-house to a large bungalow. The Door-Keeper nods to him, rings a bell. From the rickshaw, Jamal watches a woman come to the door. Latika. Eighteen, completely beautiful and rich. She hands Salim a package and goes back inside. Salim gets in his jeep and drives away. 137   EXT. JAVED'S BUNGALOW. DAY. Jamal approaches the Door-Keeper's gate-house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baba, I am the new cook from the agency. A thousand apologies, I am late for the Memsaab.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Door-Keeper grunts and goes inside. After a brief pause, he returns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She doesn't know anything about any cook. There's supposed to be a dishwasher being delivered. Know anything about that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baba, I am your dishwasher!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Door-keeper grunts at this attempt at humour. Latika appears at the gate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven't I told you, don't interrupt when I'm watching-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks at Jamal. Is silenced briefly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - come inside. I'll show you the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Latika and Jamal go into the kitchen. Who Wants To Be A Millionaire plays on the tv in the background. She turns and hugs him tight. They laugh with happiness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (delighted) Jamal, Jamal, look at you...!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Their heads are close, they might kiss. Then Latika turns away, stares out of the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ArГ© wa, Jamal....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jamal smiles hopefully at her. But there is sadness in her now. She takes her sunglasses off, rubs her eyes. There is a bruise there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've hurt your eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To see you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well. You see me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stands there, challenging. On the tv, somebody is winning money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why does everyone love this programme?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the chance to escape, isn't it? Walk into another life. Doesn't everyone want that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have another life. A rich one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who'd have thought it possible? A slum dog, with all this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you happy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have five star food, five star clothes. I sleep in a bed, not on the street. From where we come from, Jamal, that is happiness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't look so happy with a black eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You turn up here out of nowhere, telling me I'm not happy: how dare you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Voices at the gate-house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God, Javed will kill you. Here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Javed? You are with him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She throws him an apron. He gets it on just in time for Javed to walk in. Jamal turns away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First you want a dishwasher, now a bloody cook-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -I just thought-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - chup. The cricket's on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Javed changes channel and dials on his mobile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do you always watch that shit? Huh? I'm already a millionaire.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He laughs at his own joke. Turns to Jamal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, come on then, Cook. I'm hungry. Get me a sandwich.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Immediately, Sir. Javed stares at Jamal a moment, trying to place a face he vaguely recognises. Then the Bookie comes on the line and he turns back to the television.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Atcha... Latika hurries around the kitchen getting out bread and condiments, whispering while Javed talks on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come away with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ChutiyГ©. Away where? And live on what? What can you provide? What have you got, Jamal?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on the mobile)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ..yeah. He's on eighty-five. I want four lakh on him making a century. What are you giving?...Okay, make it five lakh. Javed pours himself a glass of whisky, never taking his eyes from the television.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are watching history unfold today at the WankhedГ© Stadium as Sachin Tendulkar carves his way towards another magnificent century and the record books. His thirty-eighth century- the most by any Indian cricketer ever...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Love. That will feed us, will it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It won't buy you a new dishwasher, but it might make you happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where have you been? Get in the real world, Jamal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You and me. That is the real world. Come away with me. Latika snatches the sandwich from him and gives it to Javed. Goes back to Jamal, whispers under cover of putting condiments away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're crazy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Salim will help us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Salim? You still believe in Salim? Jamal...I'll be gone soon, anyway. Bombay's got too dangerous for- She indicates Javed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think he'd tell me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Straight bat, straight bat, dammit. Then the batsman at the other end calls to take a second run.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! A single! Tendulkar seems to agree, tries to halt the other batsman with a shout, then succumbs to the inevitable and charges down the wicket. A fielder hurls the ball at the stumps. The bails fly off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no, no! stupid ben chod idiot... He flings his glass of whisky at the television. Suddenly tastes what he has been eating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what is this shit supposed to be, mader chod? Get out. Get out!

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Javed throws the sandwich at him and slams out of the room. His footsteps can be heard stomping into another room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now go, before he kills us both. She leads Jamal to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Latika, where's my bloody shirt? The Armani. Latika shouts over her shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coming! Back to Jamal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispered)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to do something for me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then forget me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll wait at VT station. Five o'clock every day until you come. She shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what, Jamal? So what? (loudly) Now, get out and tell your no- good agency not to send anybody else until they've learnt to cook. You hear? She slams the door. Hurries back into the kitchen, throws Javed's plate into the sink. The Door-keeper comes in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Madam, your dishwasher has arrived. Leaning over the sink, Latika weeps silently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Salim has his hand around Jamal's throat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why can't you let it alone? You want money, I'll give you money. Girls? I can get you girls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what I want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're like some crazy man- you're obsessed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is my destiny, Salim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Know what your destiny is, crazy boy? A bullet between the eyes. And after that, he'll kill her. Is that what you want? Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me, I don't care. Latika? She's already half dead. Salim takes his hand away from Jamal's neck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. About that, you are right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sold her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (fierce)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't sell her. Javed wanted her. He gets what he wants. He turns away bitterly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's doing alright. Get it into your thick head, Jamal. She's not yours and she never will be. 140   INT. STUDIO. NIGHT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Time for a commercial break, Ladies and Gentlemen. I know, I know, I can't stand the tension either. Don't even think about leaving your seat. We'll be back.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The lights flick back on. Prem slumps back in his chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've got the luck of the devil, yaar, I'll give you that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I- I need to-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, the toilet. Sure. Naveed, Jamal wants the bog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Floor Manager and a Security Guard usher Jamal off- stage. Prem looks up at the gallery, raises his eyes at the Director. Some show. Then he gathers himself and heads off-stage. 141   INT. CHHATRAPATI SHIVAJI TERMINUS. DAY. The clock reads five oh three. Jamal stands on the footbridge. Humanity washes around him. His eyes dart around, frightened to miss her. Checks the clock again. Six. The platform is almost deserted. He wanders away. 142   INT. CORRIDOR. NIGHT. Prem wanders down the corridor followed by a Security Guard. Another Security Guard is waiting at the entrance to the toilet. Prem goes in, leaving the two Guards in the corridor. 143   INT. CHHATRAPATI SHIVAJI TERMINUS. DAY. Jamal stands on the footbridge gazing down at the hordes of commuters. Five o'clock, five fifteen, five thirty. Six. Jamal rests his head against the railings. 144   INT. TOILET. NIGHT. Jamal is in one of the cubicles. Prem goes to the urinal. Unzips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A guy from the slums becomes a millionaire overnight. You know the only other person who's done that? Me. I know what it's like. I know what you've been through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not going to become a milionaire. I don't know the answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs) You've said that before, yaar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prem finishes pissing. Goes over to the washbasins, runs the taps and washes his hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I really don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? You can't take the money and run now. You're on the edge of history, kid!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't see what else I can do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe it is written, my friend. You're going to win this. Trust me, you're going to win.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prem leaves. Jamal flushes and comes out of the cubicle. Goes to the washbasins. In the mist on the mirror above the taps is written the letter "B". Jamal stares at it. Gradually it fades, leaving only the growing fury on his face staring back at him. 145    INT. STUDIO. NIGHT. Jamal stalks back onto the set. Sits down in his chair. Stares at Prem who looks unconcernedly back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty seconds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The digital clocks show five fifteen. Shoving the descending river of people out of his way, the seventeen year-old Jamal is forging a path up steps that cross the platforms. He pushes to the middle of the footbridge and leans out on the side railings. He scans the sea of people, desperately. Then he sees her: the eighteen year-old Latika, heart-stoppingly beautiful, over the other side of the station. A world away. She is scanning the crowd, as wired as he is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Latika! Latika!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But though he is screaming her name, his voice is swallowed by the noise around him. Then he sees two thuggish-looking men also fighting a way towards her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Latika!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frightened now, he fights his way down the steps, one figure against an army of white-robed people. He gets to the bottom of the steps, is making progress against the tide. But so are the two men. Jamal is now on the same platform. Shouts her name again. She turns with a smile. But the two Thugs leap through a train onto her platform. She sees them, starts running, is lost in the crowd. Jamal runs off along the platform after Latika.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Latika! Latika!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By the time Jamal has fought himself to where Latika was- she is gone. He whirls around, mad with frustration.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Latika! Latika!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Latika is jumping the tracks, crossing in front of trains. But the Thugs are gaining on her. He brings her down and drags her across to Javed's waiting Mercedes. Salim is standing by the car. Jamal pushes through the crowds just in time to see Salim bundling her into the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Salim!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Salim spits disgustedly on the ground. Gets in. Latika twists her head to see Jamal as the car skids off. Jamal screams with hopeless fury. 148    INT. STUDIO. NIGHT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fifteen seconds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jamal and Prem stare at each other. Prem smiles.
