dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do the right thing and in approximately three minutes you will be as famous as me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ten seconds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And as rich as me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five seconds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Almost.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four, three...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From rags to Raja. It's your destiny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...we're on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Applause from the audience.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welcome back to Who Wants to Be A Millionaire? In the chair tonight is Jamal Malik- as if we don't know! In an amazing run, Jamal has already five million rupees but, not content with that, has chosen to gamble for one Crore- that's ten million million rupees. What a player! The question one more time: Which cricketer has scored the most first class centuries in history. Was it A) Sachin Tendulkar, B) Ricky Ponting, C) Michael Slater, D) Jack Hobbs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know it isn't Sachin Tendulkar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a start. So, it could be Ricky Ponting, Jack Hobbs or Michael Slater.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll use a life-line. Fifty- fifty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Computer, take away two wrong answers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Music swells, lights dim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you were right about Sachin Tendulkar. The computer has taken away A) Sachin Tendulkar and C) Michael Slater. That leaves you a fifty-fifty choice, Jamal. B) Ricky Ponting or D) Jack Hobbs. What do you think? Decision time. For half a million rupees. Your answer: B) Ricky Ponting or D) Jack Hobbs. A hideous, never-ending pause while Jamal stares into Prem's eyes.

dialogues.speaker: D.
dialogues.text: A barely perceptible jump from Prem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sure? Not B) Ricky Ponting? The Australian? Great cricketer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: D. Jack Hobbs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know? Jamal shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So it could be B, Ricky Ponting?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or D. Jack Hobbs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Final Answer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Final Answer. D. A just-perceptible narrowing of the eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Computer-ji D lock kiya-jaye. Prem turns to the computer. Music. Lights.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With one hundred and ninety- seven first class centuries, the answer is...D. Jack Hobbs! The audience go wild. Prem's smile is thin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jamal Malik, Crorepati! The camera goes off Prem for a second. He mimes a disgusted spit. Then he is back on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I cannot believe what I am seeing here, tonight, Ladies and Gentlemen....So, are you ready for the final question for two Crore rupees- twenty million rupees?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not really, but...maybe it is written, no?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe, indeed. Okay, okay. For twenty million rupees, the final question on Who Wants to be a Millionaire? The lights dim again, the portentous music increases. Suddenly a klaxon sounds. The audience burst into nervous laughter and groans. Prem laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ohhhhh! Just when I thought I would need a pacemaker fitted, we're out of time! What a show, Ladies and Gentlemen, what a show. Join us tomorrow night to see if Jamal Malik has made the biggest mistake of his life or has just won the biggest prize in the history of Indian television....Same place, same time. You wouldn't dare miss it. Goodnight! Applause. The studio lights come up. Prem switches off his smile as fast as the cameras switch off. Gets up and pulls out his mobile. 149   EXT. JAVED'S BUNGALOW. DAY. Waving a kitchen knife in on hand, a desperate Jamal slams through the gates of Javed's bungalow, the objecting Doorkeeper running along behind. He bangs open the front door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Latika!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stops dead. The place has been stripped of everything. Not a single thing remains. Jamal runs into another room. As empty as the first. He stops in his tracks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Told you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where? Where is she?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dunno. He grabs the Door-keeper by the shirt-collar, slams him up against the wall. Holds the knife against his throat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know! Wouldn't say, would they? They had to get out fast. The police. Honestly. Jamal lets go of the Door-keeper. Goes hopelessly to the window. On the window sill is a phone. He picks it up. There is a dial tone. Jamal rummages in his trouser pocket. Gets out the battered card with Salim's details on. Dials. Salim picks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you? Where is she? 150A   INT. JAVED'S SAFE HOUSE. SALIM'S ROOM. DAY. Salim is stalking around his room in Javed's new house. Hold-alls of clothes and possessions lie around the room. A chest of drawers sits with its drawers open, still empty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where you'll never find her. Or me. You could have joined us, you bloody idiot, been one of us. You've lost everything now. Everything. Cuts the call off and slings the phone in a drawer. Takes the gun from his waist, and throws that in too. Slams the drawer shut with as much force as he can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Salim...! The line goes dead. Jamal slides to the floor... 151    INT. SALIM'S APARTMENT. NIGHT. ...the camera pulls out from Jamal's face revealing that Jamal is sitting on the floor of Salim's apartment. In the background can be heard the sound of the television. Jamal looks at the knife in his hand, wonders what he might do with it. The sound of Prem's voice on the tv.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...if you want a chance to play Who Wants to be a Millionaire, call now...! Jamal looks up. Stares at the tv. 152    INT. STUDIO. BACKSTAGE. NIGHT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This way, Jamal, this way. Great show, my friend. See you tomorrow, huh? In the half-light, Prem guides him to a stage door. 153    EXT. STUDIO. BACKSTAGE. NIGHT. Jamal steps outside the backstage door. Leans on the rail and takes a huge breath. Immediately, a blanket is thrown over his head and two police men bundle him into the back of a police van. The Director joins Prem at the back-stage door as the van pulls away, sirens screaming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's going on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a cheat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This was you? You called them? Prem shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How d'you know he's cheating?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, come on! Of course he is. He's a bloody village boy. Even when I fed him the wrong answer the little shit got it right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Director stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You gave him an answer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I didn't exactly-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Director walks away shaking his head. In the doorway, Nita is standing there, watching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nita?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But she too turns and walks away. 154   INT. INSPECTOR'S OFFICE. DAY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is all bizarrely plausible. And yet...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I am a slum dog, chi- wallah, I am a liar, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Most of you are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Srinivas comes hurrying in carrying a file, very pleased with himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shooting at Pila Street, October 19th...Maman Hossani....Victim pronounced dead at scene. Suspects absconded: two males, early teens, one female, early teen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Inspector takes the file. Stares at it. Shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you: you're not a liar, Mister Malik, that is for sure. You are too truthful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns to Srinivas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Constable. All that remains is to work out whether it was manslaughter or murder. Ten years, or life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Young Constable sticks his head around the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Commissioner's here, Sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Inspector sighs. Gets up. Accompanied by Srinivas, he leaves the room. Jamal sits there. Lets his head drop. The camera floats from the room, down the dingy corridor and out through a window... 155    EXT. POLICE STATION. DAY. ....alighting on a crowd of hundreds of people jostling to get a view of the building. News crews are setting up around them. A tv Reporter is doing a piece to camera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ....behind the walls of this police station lies the mystery all of India is talking about. Did Jamal Malik, an uneducated, eighteen year-old boy from the slums of Mumbai win one Crore rupees by fair means or foul? And in the crowds all around me there is an even bigger question. Will he be back on the show tonight to play for twenty million rupees...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Commissioner is waiting in the outer office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So? Have you charged him yet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I- progress is being made sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Progress? Have you charged him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Sir.

dialogues.speaker: 156A CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The Commissioner dumps a copy of the Times of India down on the desk. Then the Hindustan Times, the Amar Ujala and the Afternoon Dispatch thump down after them. All have photos of Jamal on Who Wants to be a Millionaire on the front page.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And if that isn't enough for you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He motions the Inspector to come over to the window. Lifts the blind. The Inspector hurries over. Looks alarmed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's-?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - yes, yes! The boy's a bloody hero with every beggar and thief in the city. We're in danger of looking very stupid, here, Inspector.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whilst I'm not convinced he actually cheated, I have got-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Inspector brandishes the file.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - Prem Kumar himself- a man of great standing and integrity- said the kid was a liar and a cheat. What more do you need?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Inspector pauses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A liar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then he puts the file behind his back. Srinivas frowns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indeed, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Srinivas coughs pointedly. Gets a steely look from the Inspector. The Commissioner has been staring out of the window at the crowds. Turns back to them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's in for fraud, so you charge him for fraud. Fast. Or you'll find yourself on traffic duty at the Gateway of India. Understand?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. The Commissioner walks out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir-?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not a word, Srinivas. 157    INT. JAVED'S SAFE-HOUSE. SITTING ROOM. NIGHT. A cheek scarred by disfiguring knife scars. Pulling back we see it is Latika, staring frozen at Jamal on the television news. A palatial living room. Dealing cards to Salim, is Javed Khan. A couple of Bar Girls giggle next to Javed and a couple of his Thugs. Pouring drinks at a sideboard is Latika. Javed glances up at the screen, clearly not recognising Jamal on a clip from Who Wants to be a Millionaire. Salim, too is staring, wide-eyed at the tv. Javed picks up the remote, doesn't even notice and switches over to a music channel. Latika hurries out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about my bloody whisky, woman? But she has already gone. He growls after her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Salim. He motions Salim to get him a drink. Javed's mobile rings as Salim goes over to the sideboard. Shifts a bottle to the back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're out. I'll just get- Syed. Salim smiles faintly at the image of Jamal and hurries out. 158    INT . JAVED'S SAFE-HOUSE. SALIM'S ROOM. NIGHT. A drawer opens. Inside is Salim's pistol. And a phone- the same one he threw in there months ago. Salim stares at both for a long time. Finally, picks up the gun and phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to himself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Final answer? He finds this faintly amusing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Latika sits in the kitchen, staring at the tv, tears running down her cheeks. A reporter is talking in front of an enlarged photograph of Jamal. Latika wipes away the tears quickly as Salim comes in. He locks the door behind him. Stares at the tv.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That boy. He will never give up. Never. He shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crazy chutiyГ©. Salim approaches Latika. She flinches as he walks towards her. He puts some car keys in front of her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ja. Go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - just drive. There won't be another chance. Go. Latika takes the keys. Hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'll kill you. Salim smiles, shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is not written.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Salim! Salim goes to the back door. Unlocks it. Opens it for her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Salim, I....can't. Salim points at the television.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have to. It'll take you two hours if you drive fast. Here. He holds out his mobile phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For God's sake, hold on to it.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Latika takes it. Salim takes hold of both sides of her head for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For what I have done, please forgive me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Salim releases her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go. Have a good life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Salim puts his hands together in blessing. She leaves. Salim shuts the door, locks it. Smiles. 160   INT. INSPECTOR'S OFFICE. NIGHT. Jamal is dozing in the chair. He wakes with a shout. Srinivas has just thrown a bucket of water in his face. He unlocks the handcuffs. Jamal looks up at him. Srinivas shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're back on the show.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The audience for Who Wants to be a Millionaire are standing in line. They are being body-searched by police. Mobiles are being confiscated and put in bags. 162   INT. BACKSTAGE. NIGHT. Gaffers make last-minute adjustments to the lights shining on the empty chairs in the middle of the set. Camera positions are checked by the Floor Manager. 163   INT. POLICE OFFICE. NIGHT. Srinivas walks Jamal through the police office, past the Inspector sitting at his desk, his arms behind his head, pondering. He watches Jamal go and then asks:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened? To the girl? Latika?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jamal stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who knows?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jamal walks on. The Inspector watches him all the way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jamal sits in the back of the police jeep. It pulls out of the police station car park into a sea of people all cheering and shouting at the jeep. Jamal looks terrified. 165   INT. CAR. NIGHT. Latika drives through the slums of Mumbai. She hoots her horn furiously at a cart-driver ambling across the road. 166   INT. POLICE JEEP. NIGHT. The jeep stops at the lights and a beggar wanders up, tapping on the windscreen. The beggar studies Jamal's face for a second, then starts shouting and pointing at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crorepati! Crorepati! Other beggars- just like the one Jamal used to be- join him and start cheering and applauding. The jeep pulls away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the chi stall, everyone gathers around the tv, watching. 169   EXT. ROADSIDE CHI HOUSE. NIGHT. A rickshaw parks up next to a hundred others. The Driver leaps out, abandoning the irate business man in the back and runs to the tv in the cafГ©. 170   INT. CALL CENTRE. NIGHT. The Manager walks into the aircraft hanger of a building. Stops. Where is everyone? Then he sees everyone crowded around the tv in the Recreation Room. Stalks over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oi! Get back to work. Then he sees Jamal's face on the tv.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The chi-wallah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All along the highway, one by one the televisions in a hundred shacks flick on, silhouetting the family huddled in front of it. 172   INT. STUDIO. BACKSTAGE. NIGHT. In the half-light, Jamal is being powdered by Nita.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good luck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prem sneers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She finishes powdering Jamal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey. Sweetheart. What about me? I'm sweating, here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She dumps the powder compact in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So. Tonight. The Calypso Bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not if you were the only man in the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She walks off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (genuinely puzzled) But I am the only man in the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The traffic is gridlocked. Latika is pumping the horn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, come on!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She glances out of the window, sees one of the roadside shacks with the television on. Gets out of the car and runs to it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Commissioner grabs his phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get me the Inspector on the phone now! 173B   INT. INSPECTOR'S OFFICE. NIGHT. The Inspector wanders into his office, still deep in thought. Switches on the television just as the Millionaire music starts. Sits. The phone rings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prem and Jamal walk on-stage. Blinding light. They take their seats to tumultuous applause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welcome back to Who Wants to be a Millionaire? I can safely say that tonight is the biggest night of both of our lives, Ladies and Gentlemen. Jamal Malik, the Call Centre worker from Mumbai has already won one Crore rupees, a cool ten million. Tonight, he can walk away with that in his pocket or make the biggest gamble in television history and go for the final question and a staggering twenty million rupees! Jamal, are you ready for that question?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. The lights dim, the music rumbles. Prem pushes the button on his computer. Pauses. Gets conversational.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Big reader, are you Jamal? A lover of literature? Nervous laughter from the audience. Jamal just shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can read.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even more nervous laughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucky! In Alexandre Dumas' book, The Three Musketeers, two of the musketeers are called Athos and Porthos. What was the name of the third musketeer. Was it A) Aramis, B) Cardinal Richelieu, C) D'Artagnan, D) Planchet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An involuntary laugh comes out of Jamal's mouth. 178   INT. ROADSIDE SHACK. NIGHT. In the shack, sitting on an upturned oil drum, surrounded by puzzled Indians in rags, a slow smile comes to Latika's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Camera on Prem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The final question, for twenty million rupees: and he's smiling. I guess you know the answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you believe it? I don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jamal laughs. There's nothing else to do. The audience groan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't? So, you're going to take the ten million and walk?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll play.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A gasp from the audience.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You just said you don't know the answer. I heard that, right? You do understand that if you get the answer wrong, you lose everything? Ten million rupees. A fortune, Jamal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A terrible pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like to phone a friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're going to the wire, Ladies and Gentlemen, we are going to the wire. The final Life-line. Here we go....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prem presses his computer. Ominous rumble of drums. The lights dim. A phone can be heard ringing, the amplified sound echoing around the studio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's ringing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The phone continues to ring. 182   INT. ROADSIDE SHACK. NIGHT. Latika is staring at the television. Then an electric current seems to shoot through her and she is running, dodging the static traffic, street vendors, the odd cow, heading for her abandoned car. Hooting horns, shouting drivers. The phone rings on... 183   INT. STUDIO. NIGHT. And on...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doesn't look as if your friend is in, Jamal. Who is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My brother's number, but-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - the sort of brother who'd go for a walk on the twenty million rupee question?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the only number I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the passenger seat of Latika's car, Salim's phone continues to ring... 185   INT. STUDIO. NIGHT. ...and ring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're on your own, Jamal. Prem looks up at the gallery. The Director shakes his head, mimes cutting his throat. 186   INT. CAR. NIGHT. Latika wrestles the door open, grabs the phone. 187   INT. STUDIO. NIGHT. Prem opens his mouth to speak. Then, out of the darkness of the studio,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello? A gasp from the audience.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello? Jamal?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow! That's cutting it fine. I'm guessing this isn't your brother. This is-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My name is Latika. The first real smile of Jamal's adult life. 188   EXT. STUDIO. BACKSTAGE. NIGHT. A small smile spreads across the Inspector's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's why he's on the show. He picks up his hat and hastens out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Javed pulls the Bar Girl from him, stares open-mouthed at the television.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the bloody-? He pushes the girl off him. Gets to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Latika! Salim! 190   INT. STUDIO/ INT. ROADSIDE SHACK. NIGHT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay! So, Latika, you want to hear the question one more time? And let's be clear about this. Twenty million rupees ride on your answer. You have thirty seconds. Jamal, please read out the question to Latika.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that really you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The question, Jamal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In Alexandre Dumas' book, The Three Musketeers, two of the musketeers are called Athos and Porthos. What was the name of the third musketeer. Was it A) Aramis, B) Cardinal Richelieu, C) D'Artagnan, D) Planchet. Silence. The electronic clock ticks loudly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fifteen seconds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm- I'm safe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ten seconds. So, Latika, what do you think? Silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five, four, three, two, one. Time's up! Your answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The audience groan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've never known.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You really are on your own, now, Jamal. Your answer: for twenty million rupees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jamal shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A. Because?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just...because.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Apka final jawab?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Final answer. A. Aramis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lights dim, the music crescendoes. A buzz runs around the audience. Prem pushes the button on his computer. Stares hard at Jamal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Computer-ji A lock kiya-jaye. Jamal Malik, Call Centre Assistant from Mumbai, for two Crore, twenty million rupees, you were asked who the Third Musketeer was in the novel by Alexandre Dumas. You used your final life-line to phone a friend. You answered A. Aramis.....which is...I have to tell you...the correct answer!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wild applause. Prem jumps up and pulls a bemused Jamal to his feet, raising his arm in the air. Jamal is smiling, but disorientated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ladies and Gentlemen, Jamal Malik, Crorepati! What a night! We have all been present at the making of history, Ladies and Gentlemen! Jamal Malik, millionaire!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Latika? Latika? To ever-increasing roars and applause from the audience, Prem escorts Jamal off-stage. 191   INT. ROADSIDE SHACK. NIGHT. The line goes dead in Latika's hand. She stares down at the phone. The bemused family are still eying her like an alien. She smiles at them and goes out. The traffic on the road is still grid-locked. She starts walking, faster and faster. Then she breaks into a run. 192   INT. JAVED'S SAFE-HOUSE. BATHROOM. NIGHT. A small tv in the bathroom. Salim smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Salim! Teri ma ki chute! Salim! Javed is banging on the door. Salim gets up from where he has been praying. He climbs into the bath which is full of bank notes and lies down amongst the money. He reaches across for the pistol and picks it up. Smiles slightly as Javed smashes down the door, pulls the trigger and shoots Javed. He falls onto the floor, dead. But the Thug right behind him shoots Salim in the chest. He lies back in the bath, the faintest trace of a smile on his face as he stares at the pictures of Jamal on the tv.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God is good. Salim dies. 193   INT. STUDIO. BACKSTAGE. NIGHT. Prem and Jamal are being posed by photographers. A giant-sized cheque for twenty million rupees is manhandled onto the floor by the Floor Manager and an Assistant amidst much cheering and laughter. Jamal is snapped next to a scowling Prem. The Inspector appears next to them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just one more thing left, Sir.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Prem smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finally, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you'd like to come with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes Jamal by the arm, leads him backstage. 194   INT/EXT. POLICE JEEP. NIGHT. Jamal sits silent in the back seat next to the Inspector as he drives through the traffic. Then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truth alone triumphs? I should have known better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Inspector stops the jeep. Unlocks the handcuffs. Holds the back door open for Jamal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thought you might need a lift, Sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He nods towards the outside world. Dazed, Jamal gets out. 195   EXT. CHHATRAPATI SHIVAJI TERMINUS. NIGHT. Jamal finds himself    gazing up     at VT station. Slowl wanders inside. The    Inspector     takes the contents o file and tears them    slowly in     half. Lets the piece fall on the ground.    Gets back     in the jeep and driv away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VT station is awash with the evening commute. Thousands of people crowd the platforms, jostling the only still figure who is sitting at the base of the statue of Frederick Stevens. Jamal. Then there is a gap in the wall of bodies that swirls around him. Jamal gets to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Latika?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then she is gone in the melee again. Only to reappear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jamal?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jamal forces himself through the people. Nothing will stop him. Latika too is shoving them aside until they are face-to-face. They stop, look at each other, hold each other's hands tight. The whole station seems frozen, the only movement from a thousand bodies being Jamal and Latika.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought we would meet again only in death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew you'd be watching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jamal puts his hand on Latika's chin, turns her head gently so that she is facing him. He sees the knife scars on her cheek for the first time. She tries to turn her head, but he won't let her. Runs his hand slowly down the scar. Rests his hand there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is our destiny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gently kisses the scarred cheek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is our destiny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The camera pulls back and back, rising above the station. The music starts and the frozen station comes alive, two thousand kurta-clad men and saree-clad women dancing in and out and on top of the trains, an unbound celebration of hope and humanity that has at its centre, Jamal and Latika.
